deity.name: The Weeping Sun
deity.symbol: A sunburst, often inscribed with symbolic rivulets of tears
entries: {@i … and the light did dim, amidst a black sorrow, and the world turned to gaze upon the moonless sky…}

The Weeping Sun, the Mourning Light. They say it drowned a world in its tears, and that our lives flourish under its light only by its mercy. We are to be greateful for its light, repentant for our sins, and always vigilant to the grief of others.

To some, the Weeiping Sun is a god of empathy, a force that reaches out to those mourning and grieving and offers them succor. To others, the Sun is the only path, the Ascendant Light, above all other deities and gods, for its role as the bestower of light. As the chosen deity of the theocracy of Lumitreinte, it is the most widely-known and worshipped god on the continent. The Church of the Mourning Light is a monotheistic religion that has sought to impose their monotheism on all those residing in the Church's territory, leading to significant animosity from those they brand as pagans.

deity.name: The Flayed God
deity.symbol: A rag stained with mud or blood
entries: {@i When the suffering is too great to bear... find solace, and be calm, for you are not alone.}
Martyrdom has always held power over humanity. A great sacrifice resonates in the hearts of mortals, and makes one into something greater than the individual.

Believers of the Flayed God are said to be able to absorb the suffering of others into themselves, bearing the pain and burdens of others in their own flesh, suffering in silence so that others may live in health and happiness. These flagellants are widely respected, though usually from a distance, as the wounds and diseases they bear inevitably leave them scarred and foul. Many adopt a leper's mask to spare others the sight of their ruined faces.

deity.name: The Rapturous Chorus
entries: {@i The first thing in the universe was the Song- perfect, pristine. Now, it permeates every fragment of matter in the universe, singing for those who still listen.}

The Chorus is a god of passion and creation, patron deity of everything beautiful and wondrous, resonating through the world. This god has few churches or priests, but is worshipped in secret meetings, in the woods and in basements: gatherings of music, dance, and pleasure. The religion of the Song is not respected by authority, but quite hard to stamp out.

deity.name: The Unbroken Circle
entries: {@i Fear not, dear child. From one perspective, this is an ending. From another, it is only the beginning.}

The Unbroken Circle is a god that few people actively worship. Its domains are obscure, and the average mortal finds little reason to be overconcerned with mouldering fungi or the grand scale of time. Nevertheless, priests of the Circle are respected and mostly viewed with respect, as the guardians for some force the average man couldn't describe but invariably recognizes as vital.

One notable black mark on the Circle's reputation is the fact that many necromancers find a kindred deity in the Circle, whose tenets hold nothing against the raising of the dead, nor the seeking of immortality. These Necromancers of the Circle are varied in their intents or purposes, but are not inherently evil- many view undeath as simply the next stage of life, and see nothing wrong with reanimating corpses to aid the living. No matter what philosophical arguments are levied, however, most people are deeply uncomfortable when the buried bodies of their ancestors begin walking the earth.

deity.name: The Burned Lady
deity.symbol: A smouldering flame, surrounded by ash
entries: {@i The flames lept across her body, and yet she did not cry out. She feels the pain, but she does not bow to it.}

Do not mistake the Burned Lady for a goddess of martyrdom. Martyrs go willingly to their deaths, sacrificing their lives gladly for their ideals. The Burned Lady holds no love for these fools. She is the god of the unwilling, the murdered- deity of those dragged from their beds kicking and screaming, thrown upon the pyre...
The Lady is often depicted with her companion, the Ashen Wolf, a great prowling hound made of smoke and ash and flame, set upon those who earn her ire.

deity.name: The Hunger of the Earth
deity.symbol: A handful of soil and teeth
entries: {@i She is no kind, nurturing mother, but a beast, all jaws and teeth and endless hunger.}

The land is beautiful, commanding both fear and respect. Mortalkind has built their empires upon her back, and feasts upon her harvest. But whatever bounty the earth gives can be just as easily revoked. She is a beast who can be befriended but never tamed, loved but not trusted. Pray for a bountiful fall and a kind winter.

deity.name: The Unblinking Eye
deity.symbol: A simple eye: a circle with a dot in the middle.
entries: {@i It is watching.}

Scholars are not prone to worship, and the Eye demands none. Many question whether it exists at all. Many of those who have delved deep into the arcane claim to feel its gaze upon them, but what proof, really, is a madman's word?

deity.name: He Who Weighs Our Sins
deity.symbol: A set of scales and a hammer
entries: {@i A time of reckoning shall come, and your sins shall be weighed upon the cosmic scales...}

The Warrior-Saint, the Justicar, the Heavenly Scribe... all are said to be different facets of a single force. Errestio Pallas once posited that the god of Justice was, in some sense, a creation of humanity- a manifestation of mortalkind's need for order, made manifest by sheer belief.

Justice is not always kind, but it is uncompromising, unbiased. Followers of He Who Weighs Our Sins are expected to be strict paragons of morality, to uphold others to those same standards... and to take action against those who falter.

deity.name: The Maw in the Deep
entries: {@i ... cast out and supplanted, it dwells in the ocean, amongst the drowned.}

Little is known of this enigmatic god. Sailors claim to have heard its voice, guiding them to safety and succor in the storm- though skeptics point out this is no proof of benevolence, as those it leads to their deaths are unlikely to report the incident. Those who have lost their way in life might find comfort in the Depths of the ocean, the sheer vastness an acknowledgement of their place in the world...
The Maw has few churches or temples. Its name lives on in superstition and rumor, in carvings upon ship decks and whispers amongst sailors.

deity.name: The Eternal Winter
deity.symbol: A diamond, enclosing a sprig of pine
entries: {@i All will be preserved in eternal perfection, encased in a sheen of frost.}

The Winter is worshipped by few southerners, but is widely respected by those who inhabit the Northland Tundras. There is no reasoning with the onset of ice and frost, and there is little point in praying for mercy.

The Northlanders consider there to be no point in holding animosity for the winter, nor in hoping for mercy. You either prove your worth by surviving on your own strength and wits, and those of your companions, or you perish in the cold, undeserving of the gift of life.

deity.name: The Last Star in the Black Sky
entries: {@i Look up, and It will guide you- in this life, and beyond.}
The night sky is filled with stars, glimmering and beautiful,  motes of light in an endless black sea.

Once a year, however, the night sky goes dark, as every light vanishes. Only one star remains, a beacon of hope for travelers plotting their path. The Old Lore says that the Star is the last thing us mortals see as we perish, following the Star as we pass from one life to another.

condition.name: Confused
entries: A confused creature can't take reactions. Some confusion effects will specify a die to roll for the table below. If no die is specified, use a {@dice d8}. At the start of each of its turns, a creature rolls the confusion die to determine its behavior for that turn.

entries.caption: Confusion Behavior
rows: The creature can act and move normally.
The creature uses its action to make a melee attack against a randomly determined creature within its reach. If there is no creature within its reach, the creature does nothing this turn.

The creature uses all its movement to move in a random direction, triggering opportunity attacks as it does so. To determine the direction, roll a {@dice d8} and assign a direction to each die face. The creature doesn't take an action this turn.
The creature doesn't move or take actions this turn.
The creature is {@condition stunned} until the start of their next turn.

condition.name: Unrested
entries: For each level of unrested you have, your proficiency bonus decreases by 1. Like exhaustion, you can have multiple levels of this condition, and it can bring your proficiency bonus below 0.
You can cure a level of unrested over a long rest if you spend 1 additional {@variantrule COIN}.

condition.name: Bleeding Out
entries: When you drop to 0 or negative hit points, you are bleeding out. While you are bleeding out, you can still take actions and bonus actions. However:

items: You cannot concentrate on any spell or effect.
You cannot take reactions. During your turn, you can take an action or a bonus action, but not both.
Any effect that ends if you are incapacitated (such as a Barbarian's Rage) ends when you begin bleeding out, though you may manually resume such effects (i.e by re-entering a Rage).
All attack rolls against you have advantage (but are not automatically critical hits). You have disadvantage on all saving throws, except death saving throws.
A slowed creature's speed is halved and takes a -2 penalty to AC and Dexterity saving throws.
You cannot take reactions. During your turn, you can take an action or a bonus action, but not both.
Regardless of your abilities or magic items, you cannot make more than one melee or ranged attack during your turn.

If a slowed creature attepmts to cast a spell with a casting time of 1 action, rol a {@dice d20}. On an 11 or higher, the spell doesn't take effect until the creature's next turn, and the creature must use its action on that turn to complete the spell. If it can't, the spell is wasted.

feat.name: Teamwork
entries: You master the intricacies of working with a partner in battle, allowing you to execute tactics with ease.

When you take this feat, choose one willing creature who also has this feat and has not selected a partner. The two of you become bonded partners. No creature may have more than one partner from this feature through any means.

items: When both you and your partner are in the same combat, only one partner rolls initiative. You and your partner both use that initiative and act during the same turn, allowing you to interweave actions and movement between each other. This shared turn starts and ends at the same time for both creatures (i.e one partner cannot end their turn earlier than the other.)
As long as your partner is within 15 feet of you, you can add half your proficiency bonus to any skill check if you are not proficient in that skill but your partner is.

entries: If your partner is killed, or you suffer a permanent deterioriation in the relationship for another reason, you may swap this feat out for another when you next gain a level, or you may choose to retain this feat (though you gain no benefits until you find a new partner.)

feat.name: Mana Absorption
entries: Your body adapts to absorb some of the magical energy hurled at you and convert it to sorcerous power. If another creature casts a damaging spell that targets you, you may expend your reaction to regain sorcery points equal to the spell's level. The spell still takes effect as normal.

This feature can only be used when a spell is first cast, so it can never drain sorcery points from the same spell more than once. Additionally, you cannot drain energy from spells that you cast yourself, and you can never have more sorcery points than your maximum.

feat.name: Mana Transfer
entries: Over the course of a minute, you can transfer spell slots between yourself and a willing adjacent target, though the act of transfer consumes much of the magic. One participant in the transfer can expend a spell slot of any level, and the recipient regains one spell slot of half that level, rounded down.

This does not function with spell slots from Pact Magic. The recipient must have an expended spell slot to regain. Sorcerers may expend and regain an equivalent number of sorcery points in place of a spell slot.

feat.name: Inconspicuous Spellcasting
entries: You learn to mask the components in your spellcasting with more innocuous actions, potentially hiding your magic from those around you. For example, you may hide the verbal components of a spell in a passionate speech, argument, or song, and you could hide the somatic components in the playing of an instrument or the workings of a tool.

You describe how you are attempting to mask the components; Hiding a verbal component requires you to make a Charisma (Performance) check, and hiding a somatic component requires you to make a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check against a target's passive Perception. Material components require no check. A spell with both verbal and somatic components would require both a Performance and a Sleight of Hand check. Witnesses have advantage or disadvantage on their passive Perception based on how closely they are paying attention to you.

You can only mask spells of the Illusion or Enchantment schools, and you cannot mask a spell that deals damage to another creature. Masking a spell does not suppress the sound involved in casting it, it just disguises it as something less obvious. You cannot mask a spell in combat.

feat.name: Surgeon
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@item Surgeon's Tools|MOD}. Whenever you make a Surgeon's Tools check as part of a Surgery, you can add twice your proficiency modifier to the check.

subclassFeature.name: Empty Hand
entries: In any society, there are thieves- those who dwell in the gutters of cities, picking pockets and cutting purses. The ignorant might lump you in with that ragged lot, but you know better. You have trained in the Way of the Empty Hand, and you needn't limit yourself to mere trifles like gold; no, you have learned to steal more {@i metaphysica} aspects from your victims.

Perhaps you learned the ways of the Empty Hand from the Monastery of Cosmic Revelation, where it originated, or maybe another disciple taught it to you. Regardless of where you picked up your talents, they are now yours, to use.

subclassFeature.name: Empty Palm
entries: {@i 3rd level Empty Hand feature}

A signature ability of the Empty Hand is the ability to move objects in and out of a small, personal demiplane. As a bonus action, you can shift an object you are holding into your demiplane, or call an object from your demiplane into your hand.

You can only use this ability on objects that can be comfortably held or wielded in one hand, and you cannot use this ability on an object that another creature is wearing or wielding, or is otherwise not free to move.
Your demiplane can hold up to seven objects at a time. If you attempt to put an object into your demiplane while it is full, nothing happens, and the action is wasted.

subclassFeature.name: Thievery
entries: {@i 3rd level Empty Hand feature}

You gain the ability steal objects and aspects from other creatures, and to use them for your own benefit. As a bonus action, you can attempt one of the following Steal options listed below on a creature within 5 feet of you; in order to Steal from a creature, you must succeed on a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check contested against the target's passive Perception or Acrobatics (their choice).
You cannot use the same Steal ability two turns in a row.
Any creature with the magic resistance trait adds a +5 to their defending skill for any of your Steal options, except for Steal Materia.

subclassFeature.name: Hollow Hand
entries: {@i 9th level Empty Hand feature}
You gain the following Steal options, which you can use as part of your Thievery feature.

subclassFeature.name: Hollow Eyes
entries: {@i 9th level Empty Hand feature}

Your eyes are now finely trained enough to identify threats and valuables at a glance. When you come across a door or similar barrier, you immediately know how many creatures are on the other side, though this does not account for invisible or hidden creatures, and is blocked by lead of any thickness, an inch of iron, or a foot of stone.

Additionally, as a free action, you can make a Wisdom (Perception) check to identify any valuables a creature may have on them; the DM gives you a brief summary of any important items they may have, such as keys, magic items, or hidden equipment. This does not identify items hidden by magic, or any item not on their person. Additionally, once you attempt this check on a particular creature, you cannot do so again until you complete a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Void Hand
entries: {@i 13th level Empty Hand feature}

You've nearly achieved the pinnacle of metaphysical theft. You learn two more Steal options for your Empty Hand ability. You gain the following Steal options, which you can use as part of your Thievery feature.

subclassFeature.name: Final Theft
entries: {@i 17th level Empty Hand feature}
You've mastered the final and ultimate form of theft, though it is a difficult and risky endeavor. You learn the last technique of the Empty Hand.

subclassFeature.name: Steal Materia
entries: You snatch a single object that is not being held or worn from your opponent. You must know the item exists and roughly where it is kept, in general terms. (For example, in order to steal a potion, you must first know that the target has a potion and that they keep it on their belt, though you need not know what type of potion it is).

If you steal an item that could be used via the {@action Use an Item} action, you can immediately use it as part of the bonus action used to steal it. This does not include most magic items, which are considered part of the Use a Magic Item action. The only exception is a potion, which you may drink as a bonus action if you steal it this turn.

subclassFeature.name: Steal Strength
entries: You snatch a burst of strength from your target for your own use. Until the end of the target's next turn, they have disadvantage on ability checks and attack rolls that use Strength or Dexterity, and they do one less die of damage with every melee weapon attack they make until the end or their nex tturn. (If this reduces it to 0 die, then it does a base of 1 damage plus modifiers.)

Once during this turn, if you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can add your proficiency to the damage roll, and you may use your sneak attack even if you do not otherwise meet the requirements to do so.

subclassFeature.name: Steal Speed
entries: You borrow the target's speed to empower your own movement. Until the end of the target's next turn, their speed is reduced by 15 feet, and they cannot use reactions.
Until the end of your current turn, your own movement speed increases by 15 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Steal Health
entries: You can only use this steal option if you have not made an  attack during your current turn.

You attempt to borrow a creature's vitality for your own. If you successfully make this steal, your next weapson attack against the target deals half damage; you gain temporary hit points equal to the damage done. (If a creature is reduced to 0 hit points, any damage done past 0 is not counted.)
These temporary hit points expire at the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Steal Luck
entries: You steal a portion of the target's luck, borrowing it for yourself. Whenever the creature makes an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, it must subtract {@dice 1d6} from the roll; this penalty ends at the end of the creature's next turn, or after it fails a roll.
You may add {@dice 1d8} to any attack roll, ability check, or saving throw you make before the end of your next turn. You can wait until you see the roll before deciding to add this bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Steal Memory
entries: You steal a memory from a creature, extracting knowledge from their mind into your own. When you steal a memory, you can choose one of the following effects:

items: You learn one memory from the creature's mind from within the past 24 hours. You can pick a specific memory if you can describe the general premise (for example, "a memory of the creature unlocking their safe" or "a memory of them meeting a conspirator"), but the information you obtain is limited to what the target knows. The target does not lose access to the memory, and once you successfully use this ability on the target, you cannot use it again on them until you complete a long rest.

You steal the knowledge of one spell from the target's mind temporarily. The spell is removed from the target's spell list until the end of the target's next turn, at which point it is returned to them. This ability does not work on Innate Spellcasting.

subclassFeature.name: Steal Heart
entries: You can only use this Steal on a creature who you and your allies have not attacked.

You quickly remove the hostility a creature bears for you. Your target is charmed by you for ten minutes or until you attack or harm it. The creature's existing allegiances do not change, however, and you cannot exert direct control over their actions.
After this effect ends, you cannot use it again on the same creature until you complete a long rest. Also, the creature knows it was magically charmed by you.

subclassFeature.name: Steal Life
entries: You can attempt to rip the vitality from another creature, claiming it for yourself. When you use this steal option, you take a -10 penalty to the check, and if you fail the steal, you immediately take 6d6 necrotic damage, which cannot be reduced in any way. If this damage reduces you to 0 hit points, you immediately die.
Furthermore, this ability only works on a creature that has less than half of its maximum hit points. You automatically know if a creature satisfies this condition.

If you succeed on the Steal anyway, the target dies. Its vitality is captured in your Empty Palm demiplane, and as a bonus action, you can consume it to regain hit points equal to half of your maximum. Alternatively, you may use the vitality to cast the revivify spell once as an action. However you use the vitality, it is consumed upon use.
Once you successfully steal a creature's life in this way, you cannot do so again until you complete a long rest.

_.displayName: holy symbol (a gift to you when you entered the priesthood)

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A {@item holy symbol|phb} (a gift to you when you entered the priesthood)

entries.name: Feature: Shelter of the Faithful
entries: As an acolyte, you command the respect of those who share your faith, and you can perform the religious ceremonies of your deity. Churches of your faith wlil provide you shelter and sustenance under normal conditions. If you take a long rest in a town where a church of your deity is active and shelter with them or spend time aiding in their services, you gain temporary hit points equal to half of your character level upon completing the rest (minimum of 1). Aiding in church services does not impede you participating in other activities during your long rest.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Acolytes are shaped by their experience in temples or other religious communities. Their study of the history and tenets of their faith and their relationships to temples, shrines, or hierarchies affect their mannerisms and ideals. Their flaws might be some hidden hypocrisy or heretical idea, or an ideal or bond taken to an extreme.

rows: I idolize a particular hero of my faith, and constantly refer to that person's deeds and example.
I can find common ground between the fiercest enemies, empathizing with them and always working toward peace.
I see omens in every event and action. The gods try to speak to us, we just need to listen.
Nothing can shake my optimistic attitude.
I quote (or misquote) sacred texts and proverbs in almost every situation.
I am tolerant (or intolerant) of other faiths and respect (or condemn) the worship of other gods.
I've enjoyed fine food, drink, and high society among my temple's elite. Rough living grates on me.
I've spent so long in the temple that I have little practical experience dealing with people in the outside world.
Tradition. The ancient traditions of worship and sacrifice must be preserved and upheld. (Lawful)
Charity. I always try to help those in need, no matter what the personal cost. (Good)
Change. We must help bring about the changes the gods are constantly working in the world. (Chaotic)
Power. I hope to one day rise to the top of my faith's religious hierarchy. (Lawful)
Faith. I trust that my deity will guide my actions. I have faith that if I work hard, things will go well. (Lawful)
Aspiration. I seek to prove myself worthy of my god's favor by matching my actions against his or her teachings. (Any)
I would die to recover an ancient relic of my faith that was lost long ago.
I will someday get revenge on the corrupt temple hierarchy who branded me a heretic.
I owe my life to the priest who took me in when my parents died.
Everything I do is for the common people.
I will do anything to protect the temple where I served.
I seek to preserve a sacred text that my enemies consider heretical and seek to destroy.
I judge others harshly, and myself even more severely.
I put too much trust in those who wield power within my temple's hierarchy.
My piety sometimes leads me to blindly trust those that profess faith in my god.
I am inflexible in my thinking.
I am suspicious of strangers and expect the worst of them.
Once I pick a goal, I become obsessed with it to the detriment of everything else in my life.

a.special: stoppered bottles filled with colored liquid

d.special: signet ring of an imaginary duke

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: Tools of the con of your choice (ten stoppered bottles filled with colored liquid, a set of weighted dice, a deck of marked cards, or a signet ring of an imaginary duke), and a belt {@item pouch|phb} containing 15 gp

entries.name: Feature: False Identity
entries: You have created a second identity that includes documentation, established acquaintances, and disguises that allow you to assume that persona. Additionally, you can forge documents including official papers and personal letters, as long as you have seen an example of the kind of document or the handwriting you are trying to copy.

entries.name: Favorite Schemes
entries: Every charlatan has an angle he or she uses in preference to other schemes. Choose a favorite scam or roll on the table below.

rows: I cheat at games of chance.
I shave coins or forge documents.
I insinuate myself into people's lives to prey on their weakness and secure their fortunes.
I put on new identities like clothes.
I run sleight-of-hand cons on street corners.
I convince people that worthless junk is worth their hard-earned money.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Charlatans are colorful characters who conceal their true selves behind the masks they construct. They reflect what people want to see, what they want to believe, and how they see the world. But their true selves are sometimes plagued by an uneasy conscience, an old enemy, or deep-seated trust issues.

rows: I fall in and out of love easily, and am always pursuing someone.
I have a joke for every occasion, especially occasions where humor is inappropriate.
Flattery is my preferred trick for getting what I want.
I'm a born gambler who can't resist taking a risk for a potential payoff.
I lie about almost everything, even when there's no reason to.
Sarcasm and insults are my weapons of choice.
I keep multiple holy symbols on me and invoke whatever deity might come in useful at any given moment.
I pocket anything I see that might have some value.
Independence. I am a free spirit—no one tells me what to do. (Chaotic)
Fairness. I never target people who can't afford to lose a few coins. (Lawful)
Charity. I distribute the money I acquire to the people who really need it. (Good)
Creativity. I never run the same con twice. (Chaotic)
Friendship. Material goods come and go. Bonds of friendship last forever. (Good)
Aspiration. I'm determined to make something of myself. (Any)
I fleeced the wrong person and must work to ensure that this individual never crosses paths with me or those I care about.
I owe everything to my mentor—a horrible person who's probably rotting in jail somewhere.
Somewhere out there, I have a child who doesn't know me. I'm making the world better for him or her.
I come from a noble family, and one day I'll reclaim my lands and title from those who stole them from me.
A powerful person killed someone I love. Some day soon, I'll have my revenge.
I swindled and ruined a person who didn't deserve it. I seek to atone for my misdeeds but might never be able to forgive myself.
I can't resist a pretty face.
I'm always in debt. I spend my ill-gotten gains on decadent luxuries faster than I bring them in.
I'm convinced that no one could ever fool me the way I fool others.
I'm too greedy for my own good. I can't resist taking a risk if there's money involved.
I can't resist swindling people who are more powerful than me.
I hate to admit it and will hate myself for it, but I'll run and preserve my own hide if the going gets tough.

entries.name: A Scoundrel and a Criminal
entries: You are associated with the Red Hand, a criminal organization that stretches across the continent, dealing in matters of profit and crime. The dealings of the Hand are many, ranging from smuggling to extortion to outright murder.

The Hand is only a loose network, and generally exerts its influence by sponsoring local criminal groups with supplies and contacts, and collecting tribute from their profits. Little is known about the leaders of the Hand, even by its members.
At least for now, your name is clear, and no law enforcement is out for your blood. Perhaps your past is behind you, or perhaps you're simply laying low.

entries.name: Feature: A Certain Acquaintance
entries: You have 'associates' scattered across the world. In any major city, you can find a contact who can connect you to the criminal underground. At minimum, this contact can provide you with the following services:

items: Arrange for the commission and purchase of some Black Market goods, items, or upgrades
Fence stolen goods, though your contact will always take a cut

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Criminals might seem like villains on the surface, and many of them are villainous to the core. But some have an abundance of endearing, if not redeeming, characteristics. There might be honor among thieves, but criminals rarely show any respect for law or authority.

rows: I always have a plan for when things go wrong.
I am always calm, no matter what the situation. I never raise my voice or let my emotions control me.
The first thing I do in a new place is note the locations of everything valuable—or where such things could be hidden.
I would rather make a new friend than a new enemy.
I am incredibly slow to trust. Those who seem the fairest often have the most to hide.
I don't pay attention to the risks in a situation. Never tell me the odds.
The best way to get me to do something is to tell me I can't do it.
I blow up at the slightest insult.
Honor. I don't steal from others in the trade. (Lawful)
Freedom. Chains are meant to be broken, as are those who would forge them. (Chaotic)
Charity. I steal from the wealthy so that I can help people in need. (Good)
Greed. I will do whatever it takes to become wealthy. (Evil)
People. I'm loyal to my friends, not to any ideals, and everyone else can take a trip down the Styx for all I care. (Neutral)
Redemption. There's a spark of good in everyone. (Good)
I'm trying to pay off an old debt I owe to a generous benefactor.
My ill-gotten gains go to support my family.
Something important was taken from me, and I aim to steal it back.
I will become the greatest thief that ever lived.
I'm guilty of a terrible crime. I hope I can redeem myself for it.
Someone I loved died because of a mistake I made. That will never happen again.
When I see something valuable, I can't think about anything but how to steal it.
When faced with a choice between money and my friends, I usually choose the money.
If there's a plan, I'll forget it. If I don't forget it, I'll ignore it.
I have a 'tell' that reveals when I'm lying.
I turn tail and run when things look bad.
An innocent person is in prison for a crime that I committed. I'm okay with that.

entries.name: Feature: Popular Demand
entries: In populated areas, you can easily draw a moderate crowd toward your performance, potentially creating a distraction or commotion.

Additionally, while in a town or populated area, you can spend your long rest performing, which earns you 1 COIN (enough to cover adventuring expenses for the next adventuring day). Performing is a full time job that prevents you from participating in other downtime activities.

entries.name: Specialty
entries: A good entertainer is versatile, spicing up every performance with a variety of different routines. Choose one to three routines or roll on the table below to define your expertise as an entertainer.

rows: Actor
Dancer
Fire-eater
Jester
Juggler
Instrumentalist
Poet
Singer
Storyteller
Tumbler

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Successful entertainers have to be able to capture and hold an audience's attention, so they tend to have flamboyant or forceful personalities. They're inclined toward the romantic and often cling to high-minded ideals about the practice of art and the appreciation of beauty.

rows: I know a story relevant to almost every situation.
Whenever I come to a new place, I collect local rumors and spread gossip.
I'm a hopeless romantic, always searching for that "special someone".
Nobody stays angry at me or around me for long, since I can defuse any amount of tension.
I love a good insult, even one directed at me.
I get bitter if I'm not the center of attention.
I'll settle for nothing less than perfection.
I change my mood or my mind as quickly as I change key in a song.
Beauty. When I perform, I make the world better than it was. (Good)
Tradition. The stories, legends, and songs of the past must never be forgotten, for they teach us who we are. (Lawful)
Creativity. The world is in need of new ideas and bold action. (Chaotic)
Greed. I'm only in it for the money and fame. (Evil)
People. I like seeing the smiles on people's faces when I perform. That's all that matters. (Neutral)
Honesty. Art should reflect the soul; it should come from within and reveal who we really are. (Any)
My instrument is my most treasured possession, and it reminds me of someone I love.
Someone stole my precious instrument, and someday I'll get it back.
I want to be famous, whatever it takes.
I idolize a hero of the old tales and measure my deeds against that person's.
I will do anything to prove myself superior to my hated rival.
I would do anything for the other members of my old troupe.
I'll do anything to win fame and renown.
I'm a sucker for a pretty face.
A scandal prevents me from ever going home again. That kind of trouble seems to follow me around.
I once satirized a noble who still wants my head. It was a mistake that I will likely repeat.
I have trouble keeping my true feelings hidden. My sharp tongue lands me in trouble.
Despite my best efforts, I am unreliable to my friends.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A set of {@filter artisan's tools|items|source=phb|miscellaneous=mundane|type=artisan's tools} (one of your choice)

entries.name: Feature: Mercantile Craftsmanship
entries: As long as you are in a city or populated area, you can spend your long rest crafting objects according to your discipline, and selling them to interested parties. This prevents you from participating in other downtime activities but earns you 1d2 COIN.

entries.name: Specialty
entries: Choose what type of artisan you are, or roll randomly on the table below.

rows: Alchemists and apothecaries
Armorers, locksmiths, and finesmiths
Brewers, distillers, and vintners
Calligraphers, scribes, and scriveners
Carpenters, roofers, and plasterers
Cartographers, surveyors, and chart-makers
Cobblers and shoemakers
Cooks and bakers
Glassblowers and glaziers
Jewelers and gemcutters
Leatherworkers, skinners, and tanners
Masons and stonecutters
Painters, limners, and sign-makers
Potters and tile-makers
Shipwrights and sail-makers
Smiths and metal-forgers
Tinkers, pewterers, and casters
Wagon-makers and wheelwrights
Weavers and dyers
Woodcarvers, coopers, and bowyers

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Guild artisans are among the most ordinary people in the world—until they set down their tools and take up an adventuring career. They understand the value of hard work and the importance of community, but they're vulnerable to sins of greed and covetousness.

rows: I believe that anything worth doing is worth doing right. I can't help it—I'm a perfectionist.
I'm a snob who looks down on those who can't appreciate fine art.
I always want to know how things work and what makes people tick.
I'm full of witty aphorisms and have a proverb for every occasion.
I'm rude to people who lack my commitment to hard work and fair play.
I like to talk at length about my profession.
I don't part with my money easily and will haggle tirelessly to get the best deal possible.
I'm well known for my work, and I want to make sure everyone appreciates it. I'm always taken aback when people haven't heard of me.
Community. It is the duty of all civilized people to strengthen the bonds of community and the security of civilization. (Lawful)
Generosity. My talents were given to me so that I could use them to benefit the world. (Good)
Freedom. Everyone should be free to pursue his or her own livelihood. (Chaotic)
Greed. I'm only in it for the money. (Evil)
People. I'm committed to the people I care about, not to ideals. (Neutral)
Aspiration. I work hard to be the best there is at my craft. (Any)
The workshop where I learned my trade is the most important place in the world to me.
I created a great work for someone, and then found them unworthy to receive it. I'm still looking for someone worthy.
I owe my guild a great debt for forging me into the person I am today.
I pursue wealth to secure someone's love.
One day I will return to my guild and prove that I am the greatest artisan of them all.
I will get revenge on the evil forces that destroyed my place of business and ruined my livelihood.
I'll do anything to get my hands on something rare or priceless.
I'm quick to assume that someone is trying to cheat me.
No one must ever learn that I once stole money from guild coffers.
I'm never satisfied with what I have—I always want more.
I would kill to acquire a noble title.
I'm horribly jealous of anyone who can outshine my handiwork. Everywhere I go, I'm surrounded by rivals.

entries.name: Feature: Discovery
entries: The quiet seclusion of your extended hermitage gave you access to a unique and powerful discovery. The exact nature of this revelation depends on the nature of your seclusion. It might be a great truth about the cosmos, the deities, the powerful beings of the outer planes, or the forces of nature. It could be a site that no one else has ever seen. You might have uncovered a fact that has long been forgotten, or unearthed some relic of the past that could rewrite history. It might be information that would be damaging to the people who or consigned you to exile, and hence the reason for your return to society.
Work with your DM to determine the details of your discovery and its impact on the campaign.

entries.name: Specialty
entries: What was the reason for your isolation, and what changed to allow you to end your solitude? You can work with your DM to determine the exact nature of your seclusion, or you can choose or roll on the table below to determine the reason behind your seclusion.

rows: I was searching for spiritual enlightenment.
I was partaking of communal living in accordance with the dictates of a religious order.
I was exiled for a crime I didn't commit.
I retreated from society after a life-altering event.
I needed a quiet place to work on my art, literature, music, or manifesto.
I needed to commune with nature, far from civilization.
I was the caretaker of an ancient ruin or relic.
I was a pilgrim in search of a person, place, or relic of spiritual significance.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Some hermits are well suited to a life of seclusion, whereas others chafe against it and long for company. Whether they embrace solitude or long to escape it, the solitary life shapes their attitudes and ideals. A few are driven slightly mad by their years apart from society.

rows: I've been isolated for so long that I rarely speak, preferring gestures and the occasional grunt.
I am utterly serene, even in the face of disaster.
The leader of my community had something wise to say on every topic, and I am eager to share that wisdom.
I feel tremendous empathy for all who suffer.
I'm oblivious to etiquette and social expectations.
I connect everything that happens to me to a grand, cosmic plan.
I often get lost in my own thoughts and contemplation, becoming oblivious to my surroundings.
I am working on a grand philosophical theory and love sharing my ideas.
Greater Good. My gifts are meant to be shared with all, not used for my own benefit. (Good)
Logic. Emotions must not cloud our sense of what is right and true, or our logical thinking. (Lawful)
Free Thinking. Inquiry and curiosity are the pillars of progress. (Chaotic)
Power. Solitude and contemplation are paths toward mystical or magical power. (Evil)
Live and Let Live. Meddling in the affairs of others only causes trouble. (Neutral)
Self-Knowledge. If you know yourself, there's nothing left to know. (Any)
Nothing is more important than the other members of my hermitage, order, or association.
I entered seclusion to hide from the ones who might still be hunting me. I must someday confront them.
I'm still seeking the enlightenment I pursued in my seclusion, and it still eludes me.
I entered seclusion because I loved someone I could not have.
Should my discovery come to light, it could bring ruin to the world.
My isolation gave me great insight into a great evil that only I can destroy.
Now that I've returned to the world, I enjoy its delights a little too much.
I harbor dark, bloodthirsty thoughts that my isolation and meditation failed to quell.
I am dogmatic in my thoughts and philosophy.
I let my need to win arguments overshadow friendships and harmony.
I'd risk too much to uncover a lost bit of knowledge.
I like keeping secrets and won't share them with anyone.

entries.name: Blade-for-Hire
entries: You used to work as part of a minor Guild Venandi mercenary company, as a hired sell-sword or battlemage. Although you're no longer an active mercenary, having taken a leave to undertake another pursuit (maybe temporarily), you still retain your old knowledge and contacts.

Guild Venandi is a savvy organization, and is paid both for their ability to enact violence and to do nothing. Many nobles have purchased a contract of protection from the Guild, which guarantees that no Guild mercenary will lift a blade against them- including you. Any local Guild office can provide you with a list of people under such protection.

entries.name: Feature: Mercenary Life
entries: You can recognize the emblems of well-known Guild Venandi mercenary bands, and you know some basic information about their members. Guild mercenaries will often share interesting local gossip and rumours with you.

Although the Guild won't allow you to take contracts while working with non-Guild characters, you still have limited access to guild files. As part of a long rest, you can request a single dossier on a well-known local figure, which contains a brief summary of their combat ability (if any) and political connections.

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A set of {@item fine clothes|phb}, a {@item signet ring|phb}, 3 COIN

entries.name: Feature: Exiled Nobility
entries: Though your family no longer offers you direct support, your name and seal still opens doors. Local nobility will often open their doors to an audience with you, and many officials will at least know your name.

entries.name: Royalty in Exile
entries: You are a scion of a minor noble house or mercantile company, banished and sent into the world. Your name still carries weight, but you can no longer rely upon their direct support or favor, until you can find some way of regaining their favor and reclaiming your rightful status. Choose the reason for your exile, or roll on the table below.

rows: A corrupt relative or associate conspired to have me banished so they could usurp my status and wealth.
I was caught in an embarassing scandal, and was banished to dissociate myself from the family.
I was implicated in a serious crime, and my family connections put me in exile instead of prison.
My family house was attacked by a rival, and I was sent away to keep me safe.
I was sent into the world to gain some proper experience, away from the coddling crutches of nobility.
Banished? Ridiculous. I left of my own accord.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Nobles are born and raised to a very different lifestyle than most people ever experience, and their personalities reflect that upbringing. A noble title comes with a plethora of bonds—responsibilities to family, to other nobles (including the sovereign), to the people entrusted to the family's care, or even to the title itself. But this responsibility is often a good way to undermine a noble.

rows: My eloquent flattery makes everyone I talk to feel like the most wonderful and important person in the world.
The common folk love me for my kindness and generosity.
No one could doubt by looking at my regal bearing that I am a cut above the unwashed masses.
I take great pains to always look my best and follow the latest fashions.
I don't like to get my hands dirty, and I won't be caught dead in unsuitable accommodations.
Despite my noble birth, I do not place myself above other folk. We all have the same blood.
My favor, once lost, is lost forever.
If you do me an injury, I will crush you, ruin your name, and salt your fields.
Respect. Respect is due to me because of my position, but all people regardless of station deserve to be treated with dignity. (Good)
Responsibility. It is my duty to respect the authority of those above me, just as those below me must respect mine. (Lawful)
Independence. I must prove that I can handle myself without coddling from my family. (Chaotic)
Power. If I can attain more power, no one will tell me what to do. (Evil)
Family. Blood runs thicker than water. (Any)
Noble Obligation. It is my duty to protect and care for the people beneath me. (Good)
I will face any challenge to win the approval of my family.
My house's alliance with another noble family must be sustained at all costs.
Nothing is more important than the other members of my family.
I am in love with the heir of a family that my family despises.
My loyalty to my sovereign is unwavering.
The common folk must see me as a hero of the people.
I secretly believe that everyone is beneath me.
I hide a truly scandalous secret that could ruin my family forever.
I too often hear veiled insults and threats in every word addressed to me, and I'm quick to anger.
I have an insatiable desire for carnal pleasures.
In fact, the world does revolve around me.
By my words and actions, I often bring shame to my family.

_.special: letter from a dead colleague posing a question you have not yet been able to answer

items.name: Languages:
items.entry: One of your choice (including exotic languages)

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: a letter from a dead colleague posing a question you have not yet been able to answer

entries.name: Feature: Accursed Knowledge
entries: You know the ritual required to access the Accursed Archive, a dark and labyrinthine library filled with ancient and lost information. It is said that every piece of written knowledge is stored in the Archive somewhere, amongst the stygian halls- though finding it is no easy task.

Accessing the Archive requires 5 COIN worth of rare components (incense, magic ink, etc), and the sacrifice of a humanoid creature's life in the hall of a library, bookstore, or similar location. The ritual takes 1 hour to conduct, and opens the passage to the Archive for exactly 7 hours.

The Archive is a dangerous place. Common knowledge may be plundered from it easily enough, but rare and obscure knowledge requires you to spend a long time searching the shelves and piercing together knowledge from various sources- all while avoiding the Archive's other denizens.

items.name: Skill Proficiencies:
items.entry: Choose two from among {@skill Arcana}, {@skill History}, {@skill Nature}, {@skill Medicine}, and {@skill Nature}

entries.name: Hunted Academic
entries: You are a minor member of the Venerated Academy of Natural Philosophers, a loose and hidden network of mages, scholars, and seekers of knowledge, forced into hiding to avoid persecution at the hand of the Blazing Rose. The Academy is heavily decentralized, organized into loose factions and full of independent personalities, and strives toward no ideal other than secrecy and survival. The singular, overarching principal of the Academy is secrecy, and disclosing information about the Academy to outsiders is to be done with utmost care- lest a leaked rumor lead to your expulsion.

entries.name: Feature: Three Days of Silence
entries: The Academy has a Rule: any member of the Academy must offer hospitality to a fellow member in dire need, sheltering them from whatever forces are pursuing them, and to keep them safe for three days. This rule applies no matter the personal relationship between the members in question, which can lead to a tense few days if a mage finds themselves harboring a sworn enemy. Once the three days are over, the host is freed of their obligation, and the guest cannot invoke the Three Days rule with the host again until a year has passed.

As an academy member in good standing, you are entitled to invoke this aid with any Academy member when you find yourself in danger, and they will provide you shelter, though they are not obligated to fight in your defense. If you invoke this aid, you are bound to certain obligations- you may not act against your host in any way while you are a guest, nor may you use any information you glean as a guest against your host in the future.

Academy scholars are, necessarily, a secretive lot, and do not make themselves readily known. When visiting a new area, it is often wise to track down the location of an Academic before you need it. An Academic is under no obligation to aid you outside of the Three Days rule.
Breaking the Three Days rule will result in you permanently being banished from the Academy.

entries.name: Feature: Custom Background
entries: Either work with the DM to decide a custom background feat, or learn 1 additional skill and 1 additional standard language.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Elvish and one standard language of your choice; common choices are {@language Aesean|MOD}, {@language Eglisian|MOD} or {@language Stellen|MOD}, the three major languages of the human nations.

entries.name: A Story told on Skin
entries: Elves have the story of their past tattooed onto them with magical ink at a young age. These tattoos depict some of the major accomplishments of your past lives, and are magically enchanted to move and shift upon your skin in minor ways (for example, depicting a past life plunging a sword into a monster's chest).

entries.name: Age
entries: Elves reach physical and mental maturity at approximately thirty, and it is about this time that their ancestral traits begin to appear, as per their Reincarnation feature. An elf can live up to 150 years, but their Reincarnation feature gives them a mental capacity far beyond their physical age.

entries.name: Size
entries: Elves range from under 5 to over 6 feet tall and have slender builds. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Reincarnation
entries: Elves are subject to a strict reincarnation cycle. Upon death, an elf's soul is transferred to a newborn body to start life anew- but every soul carries with it the memory of its past lives. A newborn elf starts with no memory of its past, but as they age, they slowly begin to remember more and more of their past. When an elf reaches adulthood, their past self begins to emerge, overwhelming and integrating any existing personality, though it takes a long time to truly reacquire all the memories and faculties of the past.

The process of regaining one's personality is a slow one that plays out in real-time. If a hundred-year-old elf dies, they won't truly feel like themselves until their next life approaches a century of age. Many elves find themselves striving to live long enough to re-achieve a past version of themselves they remember, and perhaps to live for long enough past that to build more memories.
Most elves have tattoos depicting the great deeds of their past selves adorning their body, both to indicate their past to others and to help themselves recall.

Not all elves are willing participants of the Cycle. Some elves choose to sever themselves from their past lives before reaching adulthood, claiming their lives for themselves. These elves are ostracized from elven society, and some elves even view this as a form of murder. These elves in turn consider the cycle a curse that roots their species firmly in the past. Although they can prevent their past selves from emerging in their psyche, they are powerless to force their descendents to do the same to themselves.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write two standard languages of your choice. Generally one of these languages includes the local language of wherever you are starting the adventure (Stellen, Aesean, or Eglisian).

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak Tauran, though the language is entirely oral; there exists no formalized written Tauran script.

Additionally, you know one standard language of your choice; common choices are {@language Aesean|MOD}, {@language Eglisian|MOD} or {@language Stellen|MOD}, the three major languages of the human nations.

entries.name: Tauran Horns
entries: You bear a set of great bull horns upon your head, which you can use as a natural weapon. These {@item tauran horns|MOD} deal 1d8 bludgeoning damage, and if you move at least 20 feet straight toward a creature at most 1 size category larger than you immediately before hitting them with a horn attack, they must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pushed 10 feet away from you.
Like most weaponry, your horns can be plated with other material, and can be upgraded once. See {@variantrule FORGE|MOD} for more details.
Most Tauran decorate their horns, using a variety of pigments and dyes to do so, or carving patterns into the bone.

entries.name: Charge
entries: As a bonus action, you can move up to your speed in a straight line. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all uses after completing a long rest.

entries.name: Thick Skinned
entries: Your hit point maximum increases by 1, and increases by 1 every time you reach an odd level.

entries.name: Traditional Training
entries: You learn one {@filter druid cantrip|spells|level=0|class=druid} of your choice. Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for this cantrip.
You gain proficiency in the Nature, Medicine, Performance, or Survival skill. You also gain one proficiency in a set of Artisan's tools or a Musical Instrument.

entries.name: The Nomadic Bulls
entries: The Tauran are tribes of nomadic bull-people (you might consider them minotaurs, despite the anachronism), who wander the continent and live via a hunter-gatherer lifestyle. Rejecting the laws of the Three Nations, the Tauran live by their own code, preferring to be as uninvolved as possible with the affairs of mankind. The Tauran spend their lives traveling the land, hunting for food, and tending to spiritual and artistic pursuits. The wandering tribes tend to avoid big cities, but will sometimes visit smaller settlements to trade wares.

Although some mortals cling to the ignorant image of the bull-headed brute bearing an axe and thirsting in bloodlust, the Tauran are often quite intelligent, having learned through the oral traditions of their tribe and possessing a deep knowledge of the natural world. The Tauran value artistic achievement quite highly, and boast some of the most talented musicians and craftsmen on the continent. This is not to say that the Tauran are pacifists; the bulls consider warfare to be an art form of its own.

Taurans value honesty and creativity, and tend to be a frank and direct people. Both literally and metaphorically thick-skinned, they look poorly on white lies and are open and honest about their feelings, which sometimes leads to misunderstandings with other cultures.

The Three Nations have a poor view of Taurans in general, as any state is wont to do, against people who refuse their governance, which is certainly not aided by the occasional conflict between the Tribes and Nations that marrs the record of history. This attitude tends to bleed into the citizens, and so across the three nations, Taurans find themselves less-than-liked; not actively harassed, usually, but certainly distrusted. Of course, individual opinions vary. In turn, Taurans tend to distrust humans upon first meeting them, as most Tribes have at least a few stories of malicious humans assaulting the Tribe. Settlements that have frequent contact with Taurans tend to view them in a better light, as long as relations have been peaceful.

entries.name: Leaving the Tribe
entries: Though most Tauran live and die within their tribe, some Tauran choose to leave and seek their fortunes elsewhere, often in human civilization. This is a difficult choice for any Tauran to make; when a Tauran decides to leave, the Tribe throws them a funeral, honoring their achievements within the tribe and mourning their departure. After they leave, the tribe grieves their loss, as a Tauran who leaves the tribe is considered to be deceased, and cannot return to the Tauran Tribes.

entries.name: Age
entries: Tauran

entries.name: Size
entries: Taurans are built rather larger than humans, generally ranging from 5 and a half to 7 feet tall. They are still considered Medium creatures.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You know two standard languages of your choice; common choices are {@language Aesean|MOD}, {@language Eglisian|MOD} or {@language Stellen|MOD}, the three major languages of the human nations.

entries.name: Facethief
entries: As an action, you can touch a humanoid and magically adopt their form, fully changing your appearance to match theirs. This transformation holds up to physical inspection, and is extensive enough that you can become Small to match the size of your target, though it cannot create additional limbs. Your clothes and equipment aren't changed by this trait, nor are non-physical features (such as your voice).
The exception to this trait is your eyes, which remain violet no matter what form you copy.
If you attempt to copy the form of an unwilling creature who is aware of you (or otherwise on alert), you must first succeed on a contested Dexterity check.

Your transformation lasts for eight hours or until you end it by using an action to return to your true form, or to use this trait again. Once you use this ability on a creature, you cannot use it on the same creature again until you complete a long rest.
You count as a shapeshifter due to this ability. Your true form is your undisguised self.

entries.name: Sympathetic Memory
entries: When you steal the face of another creature, you also gain a small smattering of their memories. While transformed with your Facethief trait, you gain the following:

items: Proficiency in one skill that your target is proficient in. This skill is selected randomly from your target's proficiencies, though it cannot be a skill you are otherwise already proficient in unless there are no other choices. If your target is an unknown NPC- for example, a stranger on the street, or a random bar patron, the DM may opt to simply pick a skill randomly.
One memory of the target from the last 24 hours, determined by the DM

entries: These benefits last until you change to another form, or until you revert to your true form.

entries.name: Hated, Hunted, Hidden
entries: A changeling's lot in life is an unfortunate one. Not a true race in any sense, but rather an aberrant phenomenon, children are occasionally born with mottled-gray skin, bright violet eyes, and a strange ability to adopt the appearance of others. This is widely considered an unnerving, dangerous ability, and many changelings never make it through childhood, as many communities simply abandon changeling children in the woods. Those few who survive- or had kinder parents- grow up in a world that despises their kind, viewing changelings as troublemakers and criminals at best, and aberrant monstrosities at worst. Being a changeling is often considered sufficient reason to be arrested and interrogated by the local watch, or to be captured by the Blazing Rose and whisked away to their hidden strongholds, never to be seen again.

Little wonder, then, that most changelings spend their lives in hiding, borrowing the faces of others to survive in a hostile world. A cruel cycle- mortals despise changelings for their shape-stealing abilities, which only forces them to rely upon them more. Even those who don't seek to persecute changelings are often looking to use them- changelings are naturally excellent spies and infiltrators, and most governments would be eager ot employ one- though on a very tight leash.

entries.name: A Crisis of Identity
entries: Changelings spend their lives adopting the faces and memories of others, and this inevitably leads to an amount of confusion. They very often find themselves mimicking the vocal tics of others, dreaming their dreams, haunted by memories that are not theirs. Some changelings who master the art of shapeshifting can retain a stolen form indefinitely, and craft permanent lives under a assumed face. Others become wanderers, flickering from face to face, accumulating a hoard of memories until they can't keep track which memories belong to whom. Unfortunately, changelings have a higher-than-average rate delerium and selinity in old age.

When making a changeling character, consider how they view their powers, and the storm of memories that linger within them. Do they live life fast and loose, distrusting the memories of yesterday? Do they guard their memories closely, precious slivers of passing lives? Do they prefer to steal from a sea of random faces, each a fleeting moment in existence, or do they secretly have a small number of known contacts whose faces they steal regularly, trading the distance of anonymity for consistency, and an almost vicarious experience throuhg their lives?

entries.name: Age
entries: Suntouched live unnaturally short lives, as the divine power that resides in them burns through their mortal body and leaves them empty, bereft of life and light. No suntouched lives past the age of 27.

All Suntouched have an innate sense of when their life is coming to its natural end. Every year starting at the age of 20, roll a d8 and add it to your age. If the result is 27 or above, you know you will die within the next year. (This only accounts for the natural death of a suntouched's soul extinguishing itself, and not death by external cause).

No known force can avert or slow a suntouched's innate mortality, except by abandoning the race entirely (as per a {@spell reincarnate} spell. A suntouched that refuses their natural death becomes Scorched instead, and is forced to consume an ever-increasing quantity of fuel to keep their light burning.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You know one standard language of your choice; common choices are {@language Aesean|MOD}, {@language Eglisian|MOD} or {@language Stellen|MOD}, the three major languages of the human nations.

entries.name: Healing Hands
entries: As an action, you can touch a creature and roll a number of d4s equal to your proficiency bonus. The creature regains a number of hit points equal to the total rolled. You can use this trait twice per long rest.

entries.name: Heritage of Light
entries: You have resistance to radiant damage. Additionally, your eyes are continually ablaze with a brilliant radiance which are clearly visible in dim light or darkness, immediately revealing your celestial nature to those around you. The glow of your eyes persists even through magic intended to disguise you, and even if your physical form changes (such as through wildshape or {@spell polymorph}).

entries.name: Cantrip
entries: You know the {@spell light} cantrip. You may choose Intelligence, Charisma, or Wisdom as your spellcasting ability for this cantrip.

entries.name: Celestial Revelation
entries: When you reach 3rd level, choose one of the revelation options below. Thereafter, you can use a bonus action to unleash the celestial energy within yourself, gaining the benefits of that revelation. Your transformation lasts for 1 minute or until you end it as a bonus action. Once you transform using your revelation below, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

items.name: Radiant Consumption
items.entry: Searing light temporarily radiates from your eyes and mouth. For the duration, you shed bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light for an additional 10 feet, and at the end of each of your turns, each creature within 10 feet of you takes radiant damage equal to your proficiency bonus. Until the transformation ends, once on each of your turns, you can deal extra radiant damage to one target when you deal damage to it with an attack or a spell. The extra damage equals your proficiency bonus.

items.name: Radiant Soul
items.entry: Two luminous, spectral wings sprout from your back temporarily. Until the transformation ends, you have a flying speed equal to your walking speed, and once on each of your turns, you can deal extra radiant damage to one target when you deal damage to it with an attack or a spell. The extra damage equals your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Blessed Warriors, Doomed Souls
entries: A suntouched is both a blessed and a doomed individual. They are born with a gleaming light shining in their eyes and power running through their veins, and they are said to be destined for greatness. However, this power has a cost; a suntouched is like a great fire- it burns so fiercely that it consumes itself, leaving nothing left. A suntouched does not live past twenty-seven naturally, and even otherwise potent magics are helpless to stop or slow the aging of a suntouched.

Some suntouched come to embrace their role and power, taking it upon themselves to spend their brief lives protecting those they care about. Others resent the touch of the sun as a burden, preventing them from living a normal life. Regardless, suntouched tend to be reckless beings driven by passion. Many seek to place a lasting mark upon the world in their brief existence, so that their legacy may live on past their mortal forms.

entries.name: Mortality
entries: The spectre of mortality hangs over the head of every suntouched like the reaper's axe, ready to strike. When making a suntouched character, consider: How do you cope with the inevitability of your end? Will you go gently into that good night? Or do you intend to cling to the precious gift of life?

entries.name: Dying Light
entries: A suntouched becomes a sunscorched if they refuse to die a natural death, and instead fuel the burning light inside of them with an increasing quantity of fuel. A sunscorced can theoretically live forever, but the need for fuel grows continually over time. See the Info tab for additional information.
A sunscorched does not need to eat or drink normally; instead, they consume fuel and kindling to survive. See the Info tab for details, and for the progression of the sunscorched's hunger.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You know one standard language of your choice; common choices are {@language Aesean|MOD}, {@language Eglisian|MOD} or {@language Stellen|MOD}, the three major languages of the human nations.
If you adopt this race after exceeding your lifespan as a Suntouched, you gain no new languages, and you retain whatever languages you had preivously.

entries.name: Absorb Vitality
entries: As an action, you may make an unarmed attack against an adjacent creature. If it hits, it deals {@damage 3d10} necrotic damage and you heal by the amount of damage done.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all uses upon completing a long rest.

entries.name: Scorched Form
entries: You have resistance to necrotic damage. Additionally, your eyes are suffused with a dim, orange glow, like that of a smouldering piece of coal, immediately revealing your celestial nature to those around you. The glow of your eyes persists even through magic intended to disguise you, and even if your physical form changes (such as through wildshape or {@spell polymorph}).

entries.name: Cantrip
entries: You know the {@spell scorch|COFS:A} cantrip. You may choose Intelligence, Charisma, or Wisdom as your spellcasting ability for this cantrip.

entries.name: Smouldering Embers
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you can use a bonus action to enter your Scorched Form:

Your eyes are consumed with ember-glow, and orange light seems to leak from your mouth. Creatures other than your allies within 10 feet of you that can see you must succeed on a Charisma saving throw (DC 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier) or become {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn. Until the transformation ends, once on each of your turns, you can deal extra necrotic damage to one target when you deal damage to it with an attack or a spell. The extra damage equals your proficiency bonus. When you kill a creature in your Scorched form, you can choose to absorb their vitality, healing yourself by {@dice 1d8} hit points and counting it as sustenance.
Your transformation lasts for 1 minute or until you end it as a bonus action. Once you transform using your revelation below, you can't use it again until you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Unnatural Mortality
entries: A sunscorched is the result of a suntouched clinging onto their mortality beyond the duration of their short natural lifespans. As the light inside of them threatens to die, they are forced to consume an ever-increasing supply of fuel for their divine fire, starting with candlestubs, moving onto burning coals, and then eventually drinking molten lava, iron, and the life essence of other creatures.
Every year past your intended date of natural death, roll a d8. On a 1, your hunger grows by 1 stage, as per the following table:

Though the price in life-essence is a harsh one, most suntouched are blessed warriors anyway who spend their days meting out justice. Therefore, most sunscorched find themselves in a position where they can sustain themselves by consuming the energy of the criminals and monsters they kill. Still, when a justicar sustains themselves on the lives of the punished, it has a tendency to blunt their mercy, and over time, sunscorched tend to become increasingly harsh executioners.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You know {@language Dwarvish|MOD} and one standard language of your choice; common choices are {@language Aesean|MOD}, {@language Eglisian|MOD} or {@language Stellen|MOD}, the three major languages of the human nations.

entries.name: Dwarven Resilience
entries: The Dwarven diet of mushrooms and fermented goods has given you a remarkably sturdy constitution. You have advantage on saving throws against the {@condition poisoned} condition and resistance to poison damage.

entries.name: Dwellers in the Dark
entries: The Dwarves of Sorspecto are a race that have only recently stepped into the light of the continent. Historically, they have dwelt within the earth- sometimes maintaining trade relations with local communities, exchanging ore for food, but are as a whole fairly self-sufficient, and rarely felt the need to engage with surface affairs. The dwarves on the continent are loosely unified into a single empire known as the Deep Kingdom, ruled by the Buried King. However, each dwarven city is essentially under the control of its own local ruler, and the King exerts only guiding influence on other cities.

Dwarven societies are generally found underneath great mountains, and consist of deep and grand undercities, built far below the earth. The Deep Kingdom is itself splintered into multiple cities and settlements, connected by an extensive series of tunnels. However, underground travel is usually limited to necessary usage, such as trade or communication, as travel is as dangerous underground as it is on the surface.

Dwarves are the originators of rune magic, the art of embedding mystical powers into material objects through the use of precisely-crafted runes. Dwarven society is less hostile to the use of magic than human society, and runes are used heavily in dwarven architecture and technology.
Generally, other races are not permitted to live in the Deep Kingdom, and passage down into the depths is permitted only on a per-case basis (and only granted for important circumstances).

entries.name: Life in the Deep
entries: Without natural sunlight or the surface's water cycle, dwarves have necessarily found alternate ways to subsist. Common crops above are simply nonviable for farming in the depths below, but dwarves have cultivated a very impressive selection of edible mushrooms and fungi. Edible is somewhat relative, admittedly, and many specimens that are considered dwarf delicacies would be extremely poisonous to the average human. Surface-dwellers have learned to exercise heavy caution when dealing with dwarven cuisine. Fermented foods also feature quite heavily in dwarven cooking, as a practical means of prepration and preservation.

It's also generally pretty hard to cultivate large livestock, but dwarves do maintain insect farms as a source of protein. Some larger wurm-type insectoids are even used as burrowing aides, sometimes, and dwarves have used selective breeding to get a species of mole to an impressive size, using them primarily as sources of labor (and in death, fur).

Most dwarves are so adapted for the darkness that their darkvision is near-perfect, but light is blinding to them. Their societies as a whole use very little light, and what they do use is mostly variants of glow wurms or derivative substances. Fire is rarely used for heat (smoke is dangerous when ventilation is limited); dwarves instead use geothermal heat, and many societies are built around or near hot springs. Dwarves who migrate to the surface generally lose their innate darkvision within a generation, but also adjust to living in bright light.

entries.name: Cultural Divide
entries: A few generations ago, in the peace following the Tripartite Treaty, some dwarves began a slow migration up to the surface world, trading the narrow underground tnunels for the freedom of the open air. Though dwarves have adapted well to the surface, this migration has caused a schism within dwarven culture; the more traditional dwarven sects decry those who have left for the surface, claiming that this is a betrayal of their race, and will utlimately result in the destruction of their culture. Surface-dwelling dwarves are left in a difficult position, struggling to be accepted by both human culture and their own. When making a dwarf character, consider how your character navigates this cultural divide.

entries.name: Human Variance
entries: Humankind is a varied and nuanced race. You gain one of the following features: {@feat actor}, {@feat athlete}, {@feat chef}, {@feat fey touched}, {@feat inspiring leader}, {@feat keen mind}, {@feat linguist}, {@feat magic initiate}, {@feat observant}, {@feat ritual caster}, {@feat shadow touched}, {@feat skilled}, or {@feat tavern brawler}.

entries.name: Additional Features
entries: If none of these feats suits your fancy, you can ask the DM for a customized feat to better fit your character. Generally, a feat provided by this trait should not constitute a core part of the character build (like Great Weapon Master), but should instead reflect some unique skill or aspect of the character.

entries.name: Thrift
entries: The nation of Aesrepublica values thrift and ingenuity. You have an additional four inventory slots, allowing you to carry and retrieve significantly more. (See {@variantrule STASH} for information on inventory.)

entries.name: Human Variance
entries: Humankind is a varied and nuanced race. You gain one of the following features: {@feat actor}, {@feat athlete}, {@feat chef}, {@feat fey touched}, {@feat inspiring leader}, {@feat keen mind}, {@feat linguist}, {@feat magic initiate}, {@feat observant}, {@feat ritual caster}, {@feat shadow touched}, {@feat skilled}, or {@feat tavern brawler}.

entries.name: Additional Features
entries: If none of these feats suits your fancy, you can ask the DM for a customized feat to better fit your character. Generally, a feat provided by this trait should not constitute a core part of the character build (like Great Weapon Master), but should instead reflect some unique skill or aspect of the character.

entries.name: Steel Soul
entries: You grew up in a military empire, which prioritized the virtues of hard work, endurance, and loyalty. Once per short rest, you can use a bonus action to give yourself temporary hit points equal to your level.

entries.name: Human Variance
entries: Humankind is a varied and nuanced race. You gain one of the following features: {@feat actor}, {@feat athlete}, {@feat chef}, {@feat fey touched}, {@feat inspiring leader}, {@feat keen mind}, {@feat linguist}, {@feat magic initiate}, {@feat observant}, {@feat ritual caster}, {@feat shadow touched}, {@feat skilled}, or {@feat tavern brawler}.

entries.name: Additional Features
entries: If none of these feats suits your fancy, you can ask the DM for a customized feat to better fit your character. Generally, a feat provided by this trait should not constitute a core part of the character build (like Great Weapon Master), but should instead reflect some unique skill or aspect of the character.

entries.name: Ease Suffering
entries: You grew up in a theocratic empire, and were taught the virtues of the Mourning Light, which extols empathy and compassion for others, especially those grieving.
When you regain hit points as the result of a spell or feature, you can use your reaction to cause a willing creature within 30 feet of you to regain the same number of hit points.
