Alternatively, when either you or a willing creature within 30 feet of you takes damage, you can expend your reaction to split the damage between the two of you, halving it against both of you.
You can use this feature once per short rest.

entries.name: Frost Born
entries: You have resistance to cold damage, and do not suffer the effects of mundane extreme cold. Difficult terrain imposed by snow and ice does not cost you extra movement, and you have advantage on saving throws against non-magical hazards caused by icy terrain.

entries.name: Northern Heart
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use your action to call upon the inner strength that lies into every sons and daughters of the north. Your strength lasts for 1 minute or until you end it as a bonus action. During it, you have advantage on all Strength and Constitution saving throws, and you gain temporary hit points at the start of each of your turns. The temporary hit points equal half your level (rounded up) + your Constitution modifier.
Once you use this trait, you must finish a long rest before you can use it again.

entries.name: The Harsh North
entries: You are a Northlander, a member of the nomadic tribes of the icy north, known collectively as the Cold Sun Clans. The ice and snow is a cruel and unforgiving environment, where starvation is but a season away. Northlanders cannot afford weakness, and have been forged into strong, resilient individuals who can surivve the most grueling conditions.

The relationship between Northlanders and other members of the continent is extremely rocky. Clan raiding parties have been known to descend upon the Iron Empire and the Church, forcing their militaries to guard the border against intrusion. Northlanders are very rare in the continent, so expect to be met with curiosity and suspicion. Consider why your character finds themselves outside of your ancestral northlands- are you on a mission given to you by your elders, or have you left your tribe against their wishes? Do you intend to return to your tribe and family one day, or do you seek a new home?

entries.name: Life in the Clan
entries: Though much of the lower Continent knows your people only through the raiding and pillaging, and considers the tribes to be nothing but savage, murderous barbarians, you know your Clan to be a tight-knit and protective group. Each Clan is led by two primary figures: a Thane, who is in charge of all day-to-day operations, including leading the hunters and protecting the Clan, and the Volva, who is considered the leader in spiritual affairs.

There are no restrictions on who can be the Thane, and any member of the Clan can challenge the current Thane for their position in a contest that involves hunting, navigating, and fighting. However, the Volva is a traditionally female role and is always held by an elderly lady, who hand-picks her successor and trains her from a young age. The title of Volva is transferred only upon death.
The Thane and Volva are expected to work together to lead the tribe. If there is disagreement, however, tradition dictates that the Thane must defer.

Daily life in the Clans is an eternal battle against the harsh environment. Many clanspeople are hunters, responsible for catching the meat and fish needed to feed the clan, as well as supply them with furs and clothes. Others are craftsmen, skalds, or shamans. Everyone is expected to contribute to the survival and functioning of the tribe.

Sometimes, a winter is especially harsh, and food is rare. Though the Clans will never directly abandon one of their own, there is a strong, traditional expectation that the people who can no longer carry their weight in the clan- the old, the infirm, the sick- will volunteer to leave the clan, leaving more resources for the remainder.

Though each clan is tight-knit, inter-clan relations tend to be quite icy. Northlanders prefer to take care of their own and leave others to do their same, so two Northland clans that meet either give each other a wide berth, or throw themselves into combat against each other to fend the other off. On very rare occasions, however, a single individual manages to rise up and unite multiple clans under the same cause, taking on the title of Jarl. This happens primarily in times of existential crisis, when the survival of all Northlanders are threatened- but the rise of a Jarl inevitably bodes poorly for the rest of the continent, as a united North inevitably turns their gaze down south.

entries.name: Beast Kinship
entries: You have proficiency in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill. Additionally, you can communicate simple ideas with small beasts. Once you reach third level, you learn the {@spell beast sense} spell and can cast it as a ritual.

entries.name: Blood of the Earth
entries: Whenever you regain hit points by spending hit die amongst the wilderness, you regain 2 additional hit points per hit die spent.

entries.name: Natural Attunement
entries: You know the {@spell druidcraft} cantrip. You also know the {@spell beast bond} spell, which you can cast without expending a spell slot once per long rest. Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells (choose when you pick this race).

entries.name: Child of the Earth
entries: You belong to the Llwythau Tua'r Môr- or more simply, the Seawrought Tribes, a culture that resides on a collection of verdant islands off of the coast of Sorspecto. Islanders live alongside nature, tending to the land and the beasts that live within, as they believe is the intended way of humanity.

The Seawrought Tribes are fairly reclusive and do not often seek contact with the Continent. Each Tribe has a single island to itself, and neighboring tribes are not generally welcome to visit; however, despite their isolationist nature, each tribe does pay homage to a central authority known as the Antler King, who is loosely the ruler of all of the Tribes.

entries.name: Beauty and Danger
entries: The Isles are both wondrous and terrifying, the land overgrown and thriving in its primal state. Great ancient beasts prowl the land, many sizes larger than their counterparts on the continent, and many rare specimens of flora and fauna are exclusively found on the Isles.

The Isles are especially dangerous for outside visitors. The seas that surround them are often wracked with storms, and visitors are unlikely to find the Tribes welcoming. More than one military operation has been undertaken to attempt to capture the territory of the Tribes and bring them under continental sovereignty, and each one has failed- dashed against the rocks by the sea, or cut down by the fearsome Island warriors themselves.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have darkvision out to 60 feet. Additionally, you have blindsight out to 5 feet while in darkness or in dim light.

entries.name: Light Sensitivity
entries: You have disadvantage on all ability checks while in bright light, as well as disadvantage on saving throws against light-based effects (including those that create light, do radiant damage, or impose the {@condition blinded} condition).

entries.name: Deep Magick
entries: You carry some of the magick of the depths with  you, carved in glyphs upon a runic focus (which can be a tool, weapon, or a suit of armor). As long as you have your rune-inscribed object with you, you can evoke those runes to cast the {@spell mold earth|XGE} cantrip.
At 3rd level, you can use your runes to cast {@spell darkness}, requiring no spell slots. Once you cast darkness in this manner, you cannot do so again until you complete a long rest.
At 5th level, you gain the ability to cast {@spell darkness} with your runes twice per long rest instead of once.
Over the course of a long rest, you may inscribe runes upon a new suitable object, changing the focus of your runic magic. Once you do so, the runes upon your previous focus lose their magic.

entries.name: Deep Dwarves
entries: The Deep Dwarves reside still in the underground dwarven cities, and are generally the traditionalists of dwarven culture. Deep Dwarves have pale skin, due to the lack of sunlight, and are generally slightly smaller on average than their surface brethren. All Deep Dwarves are taught at least some basic rune magicks, and in particular the ability to magically manipulate a small area of earth is very useful for survival in the underground.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have darkvision out to 15 feet. Life upon the surface has significantly blunted your darkvision, rendering it far less potent than that of the Deep Dwarves.

entries.name: Mild Light Sensitivity
entries: You have disadvantage on all ability checks while in bright light, as well as disadvantage on saving throws against light-based effects (including those that create light, do radiant damage, or impose the {@condition blinded} condition). However, your exposure to the surface light has allowed you to adapt to this trait, and as long as you wear headwear designed to protect against light (such as heavily tinted glasses or a shielded helmet), you do not suffer the penalties of this feature.

entries.name: Extra Language
entries: You know one additional standard language.

entries.name: Adapted Rune Magic
entries: Surface Dwarves have learned to adapt the old traditions of runic magic to their own uses. You have a runic focus, which can be any tool, weapon, or set of armor, carefully inscribed with runes. As a bonus action while in possession of your runic focus, you can invoke one of the three following runes:

items.name: Rune of Haste
entries: For the next minute, your movement speed increases by 10 feet and nonmagical difficult terrain does not cost you additional movement.

items.name: Rune of Courage
entries: You gain a number of temporary hit points equal to 1d6 + your level, which last for one minute. Additionally, you have advantage on saving throws against being frightened for that minute.

items.name: Rune of Skill
entries: Choose a skill or tool that you are not proficient in. For the next hour, you are considered proficient in that skill.
Once you evoke a rune, you cannot do so again until you complete a long rest.
At 3rd level, you gain the ability to evoke two different runes per long rest. At 5th level, you can evoke each of your three runes once per long rest.

entries.name: Surface Dwarves
entries: The Surface Dwarves are those who have moved to the surface, joining human civilization. Many still consider themselves beholden to the laws of the Deep Kingdom, although tensions have been mounting between the surface dwarves and the more traditionalist deep dwarves.

Surface dwarves are easily recognizable by the heavy headwear they employ to block out excessive light. They are, on average, slightly larger than their deep brethren, and exposre to the sun has left their skin significantly more tan.

entries.name: Past Self: Warrior
entries: Your past life was a warrior of considerable renown. Even if you have not chosen the martial path yourself, you can still feel old battle-instincts suffusing your body when you enter the battlefield, and an ethereal spirit guiding your endeavors.

entries.name: Ancestral Knowledge
entries: You gain proficiency in any two skills of your choice, which represent the knowledge of your past lives that has manifested within you.

entries.name: Ancestral Expertise
entries: Choose one skill you are proficient in. You have expertise in that skill.

entries.name: Self-Correction
entries: Sometimes, when your aim falters or you begin to stumble, you feel a shadow of your old self step in to correct your course. When you fail a weapon attack, ability check, or saving throw, you can choose to reroll it. If you had disadvantage on the roll, you may reroll without disadvantage. You must take the new roll.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all uses when you complete a long rest.

entries.name: Past Life: Mage
entries: Your past lives have been mages of considerable skill. Though you may not necessarily have chosen to pursue the path of magic, their powers nevertheless bleeds into you, infusing you with supernatural ability.

entries.name: Ancestral Knowledge
entries: You gain proficiency in any two skills of your choice, which represent the knowledge of your past lives that has manifested within you.

entries.name: Ancestral Magic
entries: Choose one class: bard, cleric, druid, sorcerer, warlock, or wizard. You know one cantrip from that class. Once you reach 3rd level, you learn one 1st-level spell from the chosen class's list, and can cast it once with this trait per long rest without expending a spell slot. Once you reach fifth level, you learn one 2nd-level spell from the chosen class's list, and can cast it once with this trait per long rest without expending a spell slot.

Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells when you cast them with this trait (choose when you select this race). The spells granted by this ability are determined randomly by the DM after character creation. (You may choose to allow the DM to pick out the spells rather than determining them randomly, in order to have the granted spells fit into a consistent theme, though you have no input into what this theme is.)

entries.name: The Broken Cycle
entries: You have severed your ties to your past lives, leaving you free to determine your own fate. Upon your death, however, you'll still reincarnate into a new self.

entries.name: Forger of Fate
entries: You have broken with the reincarnation cycle of your past selves, and have elected to create your own destiny. You gain one portent die you can use on allies (only); can't use more than 1 portent die on the same roll.

entries.name: Strength of Mind
entries: The training required to overcome the influence of your past lives has strengthened your will. You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed, as well as resistance to psychic damage.

entries.name: Mental Repression
entries: You can forcibly repress thoughts within your mind, burying them deep.  You learn the {@spell forget|COFSA} cantrip, and you can cast it on yourself multiple times instead of only once, forgetting a total number of different things up to your character level.
Elves are an otherworldly people locked deeply in the Reincarnation Cycle, striving in an endless quest to achieve the most perfect version of themselves through countless lifetimes.

entries.name: Slender and Graceful
entries: With their unearthly grace and fine features, elves appear hauntingly beautiful to humans and members of many other races. They are slightly shorter than humans on average, ranging from well under 5 feet tall to just over 6 feet. They are more slender than humans, weighing only 100 to 145 pounds. Males and females are about the same height, and males are only marginally heavier than females.

Elves' coloration encompasses the normal human range and also includes skin in shades of copper, bronze, and almost bluish-white, hair of green or blue, and eyes like pools of liquid gold or silver. Elves have no facial and little body hair. They favor elegant clothing in bright colors, and they enjoy simple yet lovely jewelry.

entries.name: A Timeless Perspective
entries: Elves can live well over 700 years, giving them a broad perspective on events that might trouble the shorter-lived races more deeply. They are more often amused than excited, and more likely to be curious than greedy. They tend to remain aloof and unfazed by petty happenstance. When pursuing a goal, however, whether adventuring on a mission or learning a new skill or art, elves can be focused and relentless. They are slow to make friends and enemies, and even slower to forget them. They reply to petty insults with disdain and to serious insults with vengeance.

Like the branches of a young tree, elves are flexible in the face of danger. They trust in diplomacy and compromise to resolve differences before they escalate to violence. They have been known to retreat from intrusions into their woodland homes, confident that they can simply wait the invaders out. But when the need arises, elves reveal a stern martial side, demonstrating skill with sword, bow, and strategy.

entries.name: Hidden Woodland and Realms
entries: Most elves dwell in small forest villages hidden among the trees. Elves hunt game, gather food, and grow vegetables, and their skill and magic allow them to support themselves without the need for clearing and plowing land. They are talented artisans, crafting finely worked clothes and art objects. Their contact with outsiders is usually limited, though a few elves make a good living by trading crafted items for metals (which they have no interest in mining).
Elves encountered outside their own lands are commonly traveling minstrels, artists, or sages. Human nobles compete for the services of elf instructors to teach swordplay or magic to their children.

language.name: Aesean
entries: The language of Aesrepublica (The Copper Commonwealth), one of the three major nations on the continent. Due to the extensive trade network of the Commonwealth, Aesean is treated as the lingua franca of the continent; wherever you go, you'll find people with a rough understanding of Aesean, allowing for basic communication everywhere.

language.name: Stellen
entries: The language of Stellenreicht (The Iron Emprie), one of the three major nations on the continent.

language.name: Eglisian
entries: The language of Lumitriente (The Church of the Mourning Light), one of the three major nations on the continent. The name literally means "the language of the Church", a reminder of the ubiquity and control of the theocracy.

entries.name: Special
entries: This weapon represents the natural weapon of the {@race Tauran|MOD} race; it cannot be acquired through other means.

entries.name: Bull Rush
entries: If you move at least 20 feet directly toward a creature immediately before hitting them with a horn attack, they need to make a Strength saving throw or get pushed 10 feet away from you. This only works on creatures at most 1 size category larger than you.
The DC for this feature is equalt o 8 + your Strength modifier + your proficiency score

item.name: Assassin's Poison
entries: This is a poison intended for use by the Assassin Rogue Archetype, as part of their subclass feature, and is not intended to be otherwise accessible.

You can use the poison in this vial to coat one slashing or piercing weapon or three pieces of ammunition. A creature hit by the {@condition poisoned} weapon or ammunition must make a Constitution saving throw or take {@damage 1d8} poison damage and become {@condition poisoned} until the end of your next turn. The poison expires after one minute or after it deals damage to a target.
If this poison is used by a creature that is not an Assassin Rogue, it still deals additional damage on a hit but does not inflict the {@condition poisoned} condition.

item.name: One-Shot Crossbow
entries: The compact one-shot crossbow is a favorite tool of cutthroats and assassins- at least, those who can afford it. The one-shot is a slender spring-loaded crossbow, scarce more than a pipe, that can easily be concealed in one's sleeve, and can instantly fire a bolt at a moment's notice.

Though in theory a simple concept, the craftsmanship on one-shot crossbows is quite delicate- after all, the weapon packs quite a lot of pressure into a very small space, concentrated into a very sharp point which is very close to your very own hand. Amongst less reputable circles, stories abound of amateur thugs buying cheap one-shots and discovering that the nickname "Two-Finger Jimmy" comes with it, free of charge.
Most reputable weaponsmiths do not produce or sell one-shot crossbows, and negotiating the purchase of one often requires a visit to less innocent circles.

entries.name: Special
entries: The one-shot must be installed along the arm to use, and takes one minute to equip. You do not need a free hand to operate the one-shot, although you cannot install more than one on a single arm, nor can you install it alongside similar items that occupy the forearm.
When you roll initiative, you may immediately expend your reaction to fire the one-shot, or you may fire it as a bonus action during your turn.
Loading the one-shot requires a significant amount of strength and effort, and one minute of time.

entries.name: Dangerous
entries: If you are not proficient with the one-shot and attempt to use it, there is a fifty percent chance it backfires, dealing {@damage 3d8} piercing damage and disabling the use of your arm for one minute.

item.name: Kidnapper's Draught
entries: This injury poison contains a potent paralytic that infects the blood and causes wounds to congeal.

As an action, you may coat one weapon or one piece of ammunition with this poison, which lasts for ten minutes before losing potency. If a creature is subjected to this poison while at 10% of their maximum hit points or lower (or has 10 or less hit points in total), they are immediately {@condition poisoned} for one hour. While poisoned in this way, they are also {@condition paralyzed}. If are reduced to 0 hit points by the blow that applies this poison, they do not die and are stable.
If the target receives any healing or takes damage, the {@condition poisoned} condition immediately ends.
This poison does not affect any creature that does not have blood.

entries.name: The Assassin's Friend
entries: {@i A favorite of kidnappers and ransomeers. A strange venom, intended not to cause death but to preserve life. Of course, we know that there are fates far worse than death.}
- taken from the writings of an unnamed Venandi assassin.

item.name: Holy Staff (Radiant)
entries: {@i A tall, metal staff, with the symbol of your god or faith affixed to the tip. Radiant staffs are generally made of gold-plated brass.}
Spells you cast through this staff ignore resistance to radiant damage.

item.name: Holy Staff (Necrotic)
entries: {@i A tall, metal staff, with the symbol of your god or faith affixed to the tip. Necrotic staffs are generally made of silver-plated brass.}
Spells you cast through this staff ignore resistance to necrotic damage.

item.name: Primal Staff (Venom)
entries: {@i A long length of knobbled wood, decorated with symbols of primal power- feathers, bones, vines, and other adornments of nature.}
Spells you cast through this staff ignore resistance to acid and poison damage.

item.name: Primal Staff (Fire)
entries: {@i A long length of knobbled wood, decorated with symbols of primal power- feathers, bones, vines, and other adornments of nature.}
Spells you cast through this staff ignore resistance to fire damage.

item.name: Primal Staff (necrotic)
entries: {@i A long length of knobbled wood, decorated with symbols of primal power- feathers, bones, vines, and other adornments of nature.}
Spells you cast through this staff ignore resistance to necrotic damage.

item.name: Primal Staff (Physical)
entries: {@i A long length of knobbled wood, decorated with symbols of primal power- feathers, bones, vines, and other adornments of nature.}

When you cast a spell through this staff that does bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage, you can add your wisdom modifier to the damage. This only works on the first damage roll of a spell, and this does not let you add your wisdom modifier more than once on a particular damage roll.

item.name: Arcane Staff (Fire)
entries: {@i A polished length of cured wood or metal, topped with a crystal or other focus.}
Spells you cast through this staff ignore resistance to fire damage.

item.name: Arcane Staff (Cold)
entries: {@i A polished length of cured wood or metal, topped with a crystal or other focus.}
Spells you cast through this staff ignore resistance to cold damage.

item.name: Arcane Staff (Lightning)
entries: {@i A polished length of cured wood or metal, topped with a crystal or other focus.}
Spells you cast through this staff ignore resistance to lightning damage.

item.name: Arcane Staff (Necrotic)
entries: {@i A polished length of cured wood or metal, topped with a crystal or other focus.}
Spells you cast through this staff ignore resistance to fire damage.

item.name: Upgrade: Rope Winch
entries: {@i Requirements: A thrown weapon}

You attach a reinforced wire to your weapon, connected to a small winch mechanism on your arm. The wire extends up to 60 feet, and as a bonus action you can cause the wire to retract, returning the weapon to your hand.

If a thrown rope weapon hits a creature, it is stuck in them until they take an action to pull it out or you use the winch to retract it. The winch is not strong enough to move a creature by itself, but as an attack, you may attempt a contested Athletics check to forcibly drag them 15 feet closer to you. The roped creature may attempt the same check to drag you closer. Any creature that cannot be grappled or restrained, or is otherwise incorporeal, cannot be roped.

While your weapon is thrown, the wire is exposed. The wire has AC 15 and breaks if it takes at least 10 fire or slashing damage from a single attack or effect. A broken wire can be easily repaired out of combat, requiring only 10 minutes of time.
The wire is sturdy enough to support the weight of a single medium creature, though the winch cannot move you against the force of gravity.

entries.name: Additional Upgrades
entries: You may take this upgrade a second time, strengthening the wire-winch mechanism. If you do so, you may retract the rope without expending a bonus action, but only during your turn. Furthermore, the mechanism is strengthened to the point where it can support your weight and move you upward. As an action, while your hook is embedded in a surface or a sturdy object, or a creature at least 2 size categories larger than you, and you have a clear path to the hook, you can retract it and grapple to the hook, moving to its location.
Additionally, the rope now only breaks if it takes at least 20 slashing or fire damage from a single attack or effect.

item.name: Upgrade: Aerodynamic
entries: {@i Requirements: A thrown weapon}
The normal range of this weapon increases to 60 feet. If thrown at a target within 20 feet (but not at an adjacent target), the weapon deals bonus damage.

item.name: Upgrade: Armor Piercing
entries: {@i Requirements: piercing damage weapon}
This weapon ignores Damage Reduction up to your proficiency modifier.

entries.name: Damage Reduction
entries: Many heavily armored creatures (as well as heavy armor) have gained a level of damage reduction, which reduces every instance of damage they take by a flat amount.

item.name: Upgrade: Vicious
entries: {@i Requirements: A x weapon}
A vicious damage deals bonus damage on a critical hit. This bonus damage is applied {@i after} the crit, so it is not doubled.

entries.name: Additional Upgrades
entries: If you take this upgrade a second time, it instead deals double bonus damage on a crit. If you take it a third time, it instead deals four times bonus damage on a crit.

item.name: Upgrade: Adaptable
entries: This weapon has been modified to be used in different ways. Choose one physical damage type: bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing. When you attack with this weapon, you may have it deal damage of either type, though you must decide before the DM narrates the result of the damage.

entries.name: Additional Upgrades
entries: If you take the upgrade a second time, your weapon can deal any of the three physical damage types when it hits.

item.name: Upgrade: Flourish
entries: You've added some particularly reflective or noisy components to your weapon, allowing you to distract your opponents from a distance. When you take the {@action Attack} action, you may replace one attack with the Help action against a hostile creature within 30 feet of yourself.

item.name: Upgrade: Concealed
entries: {@i Requirements: A light weapon}

This weapon has been disguised, allowing you to easily conceal it. This disguise takes on a form of your choice, though it must be logical and unassuming- a dagger may be disguised as a pen (or perhaps even cleverly sewn into a hat, or made into a large hairpin), while a sword might be hidden in a cane or a staff.

A creature does not recognize your disguised weapon as a weapon unless they succeed on a DC 20 Investigation check. If you ever make a Deception or Performance check to ambush a creature with this weapon, you have advantage on that check. Finally, this weapon does not register as a weapon for divination spells such as Locate Object, though it can still be located via divination by other means.

item.name: Upgrade: Elongated
entries: {@i Requirements: not light, and not reach}
This weapon gains the Reach property.

item.name: Upgrade: Defender
entries: {@i Requirements: not light}

This weapon has been adapted to be more effective at defending others. When a creature other than yourself within your reach is hit by an attack, you can expend your reaction to parry the blow, increasing their AC by 3 against the triggering attack and potentially causing it to miss.

item.name: Upgrade: Hooked
entries: A hook is welded upon the weapon, allowing you to grapple enemies with it. This weapon can be used to maintain a grapple in place of a free hand. When you hit a creature with this weapon, you can use your bonus action to attempt to grapple it (making a contested ability check as usual).
A hooked weapon can grapple only one creature at a time. While grappling a creature, it can only attack that creature, and it deals only half damage.

item.name: Upgrade: Massive
entries: {@i Requirements: A heavy weapon}
A massive weapon requires a Strength score of 15 or higher to wield.

Whenever you take the {@action Attack} action with a Massive weapon, you lose the benefits of Extra Attack and any other feature that would grant you more than one attack. For each attack sacrificed in this way, you deal bonus damage three times.

item.name: Upgrade: Quick
entries: {@i Requirements: not heavy}
The weapons' damage dice downscales by one step. Whenever you take the Attack action and make an attack with this weapon, you can make one more attack with it as a bonus action.

item.name: Upgrade: Executioner
entries: Whenever you attack a {@condition prone} or {@condition grappled} creature with this weapon, it deals bonus damage.

item.name: Upgrade: Welded
entries: This weapon has been welded directly to a gauntlet. If this item had the Thrown property, it loses it. You cannot be disarmed of this weapon.
This weapon also cannot be dropped; you may remove the weapon and its gauntlet by spending an action.

item.name: Upgrade: Powerful
entries: The weapon's damage die upscales by one step.

entries.name: Additional Upgrades
entries: You may take this upgrade up to 3 times.

item.name: Upgrade: Stancebreaker
entries: {@i Requirements: not light}

This weapon has been designed to let you disrupt an opponent's stance. When you attack an opponent that is no more than one size category larger than you, you can choose to deal half damage on your attack and impose disadvantage on the next Strength or Dexterity saving throw they make before the end of your next turn.

item.name: Upgrade: Combo
entries: {@i Requirements: d6 or greater damage die}
Downscale the weapon's damage die by one step. Once per turn, if you land two or more attacks against the same creature with this weapon, deal bonus damage.

entries.name: Additional Upgrades
entries: If you take this upgrade again, you downscale the weapon's damage die again, but you lose the 'once per turn' restriction, allowing you to deal bonus damage on {@i every} subsequent hit past the first.

item.name: Upgrade: Precise
entries: {@i Requirements: not heavy}
This upgrade trades power for accuracy. You have a +2 to damage rolls with this weapon, but you take a -4 to damage rolls.

item.name: Poisoner's Kit
entries: A poisoner's kit includes the vials, chemicals, and other equipment necessary for the creation of poisons. Proficiency with this kit lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make to craft or use poisons, as well as checks made to harvest poisons or poisonous materials.
Checks made to harvest poison often use Dexterity as the base stat, while crafting poisons is usually Intelligence.

If you are proficient, you can use a poisoner's kit create two vials of {@item basic poison(vial)|PHB|basic poison} over a long rest at no cost. These potions are worth no money, and expire when you take another long rest.

item.name: Thieves' Tools
entries: This set of tools includes a small file, a set of lock picks, a small mirror mounted on a metal handle, a set of narrow-bladed scissors, and a pair of pliers. Proficiency with these tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make to disarm traps or open locks.

item.name: Infiltrator's Kit
entries: The infiltrator's kit contains a small pouch of makeup and disguises, as well as a selection of parchment, papers, and inks- all the necessary material to make a disguise and forge doguments. You may add your proficiency bonus to any check relating to the creation of a visual disguise or the forging of a document.

Over the course of 10 minutes, you can craft a disguise that conceals your identity. It does not include clothing, but does include smaller accessories (glasses, fake jewelry, makeup, etc). While wearing this disguise, you have advantage on ability checks made to maintain the ruse.

Over the course of 1 hour, you can forge a copy of a document. You must have a copy of the document at hand during that time, and you can create a near-perfect copy, modifying parameters of the document as you see fit (such as changing names). A creature checking the validity of the document must succeed on a DC 15 Investigation check; on a failure, they can find no flaws. At 11th level, the DC grows to 20.

Generally, these forgeries aren't perfect, and a careful examination over several hours will reveal defects. Most documents are not subject to such rigorous examination, however- a guard will give a document only a passing glance.

item.name: Alchemist's Supplies
entries: This alchemist's kit contains a number of basic instruments and reagents core to any alchemist's lab. Proficiency with this kit allows you to add your proficiency to any check made to identify or otherwise safely interact with potions or alchemical reagents.

If you are proficient, you may use these tools to craft two {@item potions of healing} over the course of a long rest at no cost. These potions are worth no COIN, and expire if unused at the end of your next long rest.

item.name: Smith's Tools
entries: A set of smith's tools contain a set of hammers, tongs, and other basic portable supplies. It's no substitute for a true forge, but it allows basic repairs and maintenance to be done on the go.

If you are proficient in smith's tools, you can spend a short rest repairing the damage done to a single piece of nonmagical weaponry or armor, as long as it has not been fully destroyed. This is particularly useful when dealing with acidic creatures.

Additionally, over the course of a long rest, you can use smith's tools to improve a nonmagical weapon, granting it a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls. This bonus does not make the weapon magical, nor does it stack with similar bonuses. This improvement lasts until you complete a long rest.

item.name: Surgeon's Tools
entries: A surgeon's kit contains a set of scalpels, bandages, and other medical equipment. Ideally one never needs to use this kit, but adventuring is a risky business...

Proficiency with surgeon's tools allow you to add your proficiency bonus to Surgery checks, which are made to treat {@variantrule lingering injuries|MOD}. Surgery checks usually use Intelligence or Dexterity as the base stat

item.name: Healer's Kit
entries: This kit is a leather pouch containing bandages, salves, and splints. The {@feat Healer} feat is required to properly use a Healer's kit.

variant.name: Material: Moonsilver
entries: A purer variant of silver, which can only be extracted from rare nodes on the surface of the moon's corpse. Difficult to extract, only the most skilled craftsmen can work this metal without ruining its purity.
Moonsilver weapons must be commissioned from legendary smiths, and the material must be provided by the customer. It costs at least 10 COIN to plate a weapon with moonsilver.

entries.name: Moonsilver
entries: Moonsilver weapons pierce and rend monstrosities, celestials, aberrations, and lunar creatures. Its bonus damage is necrotic.

entries.name: Moonsilver
entries: Moonsilver weapons pierce and rend monstrosities, celestials, aberrations, and lunar creatures. Its bonus damage is necrotic.

variant.name: Material: Silver
entries: Hunters often use silvered blades to hunt dangerous monsters. A fairly standard material, but useful nonetheless.
Silver weapons can be commissioned from local smiths, and the material is generally readily available. It costs 1 COIN to have a weapon plated in silver.

entries.name: Silver
entries: Silver weapons pierce monstrosities.

entries.name: Silver
entries: Silver weapons pierce monstrosities.

variant.name: Material: Deep Lead
entries: The signature weapons of the Order of the Blazing Rose, deep-lead weapons carry inherent anti-magic properties that are extremely useful when fighting mages. This material can never be applied to a magic weapon.

As the Blazing Rose is the sole producer of deep lead, it is difficult to acquire the necessary material to create one- and public ownership of a deep lead weapon tends to draw the attention of the Order.

Deep Lead weapons must be commissioned from expert smiths, and the material must be provided by the customer. Some smiths may outright refuse the order, wishing to avoid entanglement with the Blazing Rose. It costs a minimum of 5 COIN to have a weapon plated with Deep Lead.

entries.name: Deep Lead
entries: Deep lead weapons pierce and rend any fey, spellcaster, or psion, although this excludes non-psionic Innate Spellcasting (as these generally represent innate abilities rather than true magic). Its bonus damage is cold.
Any concentration save triggered by a deep lead weapon has a minimum DC of 15. Additionally, deep lead weapons are immune to spells and magical effects that directly target them.
A spellcaster or psion who holds a deep lead weapon is {@condition poisoned} and cannot cast spells or use psionic powers until they release the weapon.

entries.name: Deep Lead
entries: Deep lead weapons pierce and rend any fey, spellcaster, or psion, although this excludes non-psionic Innate Spellcasting (as these generally represent innate abilities rather than true magic). Its bonus damage is cold.
Any concentration save triggered by a deep lead weapon has a minimum DC of 15. Additionally, deep lead weapons are immune to spells and magical effects that directly target them.
A spellcaster or psion who holds a deep lead weapon is {@condition poisoned} and cannot cast spells or use psionic powers until they release the weapon.

variant.name: Material: Blessed Gold
entries: Although gold is normally an impractical material for weaponry, being soft, malleable, and expensive, it does have the unique property of being able to bear and retain holy enchantments. As such, it can be laced with divine blessings to create a weapon that cuts through creatures of darkness with ease.
Goldblessed weapons are disabled in an antimagic field.

Goldblessed weapons must be commissioned from expert smiths, with the aid of an expert good-aligned cleric. However, the fine enchantments are extremely difficult to work on smaller weaponry: applying blessed gold to a light or finesse weapon requires the service of a legendary smith and legendary cleric, at a minimum of four times the normal cost. It costs a minimum of 5 COIN to have a weapon plated with Blessed Gold (20 COIN for light or finesse weapons)

entries.name: Blessed Gold
entries: Goldblessed weapons pierce and rend undead and fiends. Its bonus damage is radiant.

entries.name: Blessed Gold
entries: Goldblessed weapons pierce and rend undead and fiends. Its bonus damage is radiant.

variant.name: Material: Quicksilver
entries: Despite its name, quicksilver isn't another variant of silver- it's {@i mercury}, a liquid metal poisonous to most mortals and beasts. It is extraordinarily difficult to work onto a weapon, as it is liquid at room temperature- as such, a quicksilvered blade must be laced with intense cold enchantments to retain its solid form. Once created, however, they are singularly cruel weapons, as any wound upon the opponent allows fragments of frozen mercury to break free of the blade, entering the bloodstream and poisoning the target.
Quicksilver weapons must be commissioned from legendary smiths. It costs at least 10 COIN to plate a weapon with quicksilver.

entries.name: Quicksilver
entries: Quicksilver weapons pierce and rend humanoids, beasts, and monstrosities. Their bonus damage is poison.
Quicksilver weapons break and must be reforged if the cold enchantments upon them are broken.

entries.name: Quicksilver
entries: Quicksilver weapons pierce and rend humanoids, beasts, and monstrosities. Their bonus damage is poison.
Quicksilver weapons break and must be reforged if the cold enchantments upon them are broken.

variant.name: Material: Leviathan Bone
entries: Normal bone makes for crude weaponry, suitable for hunting beasts and bandits, but fragile and susceptible to breakage against sturdier foes. In the northlands, however, there are barbarians who harvest the bones of a long-dead Leviathan, fashioning it into weaponry and armor. Immensely durable, these bones can retain an edge for years without dulling, and are capable of piercing thick hides.

Leviathan bone weapons must be commissioned from a local craftsman familiar with Leviathan bone. Most such craftsmen are found in the northern tundras, amongst the nomadic tribes of the Cold Sun Clans. Due to their surprisingly light weight, Leviathan Bone is unsuitable for crafting bludgeoning weapons. Bone weapons cost 2 COIN more than their standard counterparts.

entries.name: Leviathan Bone
entries: Leviathan weapons pierce giants and dragons.

entries.name: Leviathan Bone
entries: Leviathan weapons pierce giants and dragons.

variant.name: Material: Steel
entries: Most weapons and armor in Sorspecto is made of bronze, which sets the baseline standard for weapons and armor. However, the military regime of the Iron Empire has developed iron and steel weaponry, and through the Tripartite Treaty has enforced exclusive ownership of the smelting process. Ownership of iron and steel weaponry is considered a right reserved for soldiers of the Empire, and displaying one in public is grounds for confiscation and interrogation. Most individuals find a bronze blade sufficient for their purposes, but even a small advantage multiplied over a thousand soldiers gives the Empire a significant edge in miltary conflict.

Steel weaponry offers no inherent mystic bonus, but they do offer a +1 to attack and damage rolls (which does not stack with any similar bonus.) Additionally, as the steel makes up the body of the weapon rather than the plating, it is the only base material that can be combined with other materials, allowing for silver-plated steel weaponry and similar. However, a magic weapon cannot have this material applied to it.

Steel weapons must be commissioned from expert smiths familiar with forging steel. Unfortunately, such smiths generally reside in the Empire, and as such are forbidden to craft such blades for non-empire soldiers. Steel weaponry costs at least 3 COIN more than equivalent bronze weaponry.

entries.name: Steel
entries: Steel weapons have a +1 to attack and damage rolls.

entries.name: Steel
entries: Steel weapons have a +1 to attack and damage rolls.

itemGroup.name: Arcane Staff
entries: {@i A polished length of cured wood or metal, topped with a crystal or other focus.}
Arcane staffs come in a great variety of types. Some example staffs are given below, but you can usually acquire a staff that pierces any non-physical damage type as a standard item.

itemGroup.name: Primal Staff
entries: {@i A long length of knobbled wood, decorated with symbols of primal power- feathers, bones, vines, and other adornments of nature.}
Druids have some of the most varied damage types. Some suggested types are given, but you can usually find a staff for any particular damage type.

itemGroup.name: Holy Staff
entries: {@i A tall, metal staff, with the symbol of your god or faith affixed to the tip. Holy staffs are often made with a core of brass, plated with gold or silver.}
Radiant and Necrotic holy staffs are by far the most common, but the clerics of certain deities are known to use variations; for example, the clerics of the Burned Lady often use a fire variant.

entries.name: Upgrade
entries: This item represents an upgrade that can be applied to certain weapons. A weapon can bear no more than three upgrades at a time. The first upgrade costs 3 COIN to apply; the next costs 7 COIN and requires the service of an expert smith, and the last upgrade costs a whopping 12 COIN and requires a legendary craftsman. Unless the upgrade specifies otherwise, you cannot apply the same upgrade to a weapon more than once. See {@variantrule FORGE|MOD} for additional details.
A magic weapon can bear no more than one upgrade, and it costs 12 COIN to apply. Some upgrades can only be applied to certain weapons. At this point, upgrades can only be applied to melee weapons.
This section on variant, optional, and expanded rules has been curated for my games. Generally, the rules here are the ones that are in play in my campaigns.
Occasionally, there are "rules" that are actually negative rules, such as "no (magic item) crafting". These exist mostly so players know what to expect.
Some of the rules here are tagged with Optional or Variant. You should understand these as follows

entries.name: Untagged
entries: If a rule listed here lacks both the Optional and Variant tags, you should consider it an official rule or ruling that will be in play.

entries.name: Optional
entries: Optional rules generally provide additional choices for players, but are not mandatory to use. Most of these rules cover player features.

entries.name: Variant
entries: Variant rules are rules that are not always in play during my games, but I may sometimes choose to use when the situation calls for it. This is primarily for systems like the rules on Madness that don't tend to come up often, but which I prefer to keep around for reference. Feel free to filter these out.

variantrule.name: Action Options
entries: This section provides new action options for combat.

entries.name: Climb onto a Bigger Creature
entries: If one creature wants to jump onto another creature, it can do so by grappling. A small or Medium creature has little chance of making a successful grapple against a Huge or Gargantuan creature, however, unless magic has granted the grappler supernatural might.

As an alternative, a suitably large opponent can be treated as terrain for the purpose of jumping onto its back or clinging to a limb. After making any ability checks necessary to get into position and onto the larger creature, the smaller creature uses its action to make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check contested by the target's Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. If it wins the contest, the smaller creature successfully moves into the target creature's space, the smaller creature moves with the target and has advantage on attack rolls against it.

The smaller creature can move around within the larger creature's space, treating the space as difficult terrain. The larger creature's ability to attack the smaller creature depends on the smaller creature's location, and is left to your discretion. The larger creature can dislodge the smaller creature as an action—knocking it off, scraping it against a wall, or grabbing and throwing it—by making a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check contested by the smaller creature's Strength ({@skill Athletics}) or Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check. The smaller creature chooses which ability to use.

entries.name: Overrun
entries: When a creature tries to move through a hostile creature's space, the mover can try to force its way through by overrunning the hostile creature. As an action or a bonus action, the mover makes a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check contested by the hostile creature's Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. The creature attempting the overrun has advantage on this check if it is larger than the hostile creature, or disadvantage if it is smaller. If the mover wins the contest, it can move through the hostile creature's space once this turn.

entries.name: Shove Aside
entries: With this option, a creature uses the special {@action shove} attack from the Player's Handbook to force a target to the side, rather than away. The attacker has disadvantage on its Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check when it does so. If that check is successful, the attacker moves the target 5 feet to a different space within its reach.

variantrule.name: Ability Scores: Point Buy
entries: Generally, in any of my games, you use this variant instead of rolling for stats.

You have 27 points to spend on your ability scores. The cost of each score is shown on the Ability Score Point Cost table. For example, a score of 14 costs 7 points. Using this method, 15 is the highest ability score you can end up with, before applying racial increases. You can't have a score lower than 8.

This method of determining ability scores enables you to create a set of three high numbers and three low ones (15, 15, 15, 8, 8, 8), a set of numbers that are above average and nearly equal (13, 13, 13, 12, 12, 12), or any set of numbers between those extremes.
Alternatively, see the

variantrule.name: Crafting Magic Items
entries: Players do not generally have the ability to create magic items. In Sorspecto, most magic items are a relic of an older age, and the ability to create more is an exceedingly rare talent.

variantrule.name: Diagonals
entries: This rule is in play when we have a battlemap on FoundryVTT. It is not something you need to consciously remember, as Foundry automatically calculates distances by this rule- but I am leaving it here for completeness.

The {@i Player's Handbook} presents a simple method for counting movement and measuring range on a grid: count every square as 5 feet, even if you're moving diagonally. Though this is fast in play, it breaks the laws of geometry and is inaccurate over long distances. This optional rule provides more realism, but it requires more effort during combat.

When measuring range or moving diagonally on a grid, the first diagonal square counts as 5 feet, but the second diagonal square counts as 10 feet. This pattern of 5 feet and then 10 feet continues whenever you're counting diagonally, even if you move horizontally or vertically between different bits of diagonal movement.
For example, a character might move one square diagonally (5 feet), then three squares straight (15 feet), and then another square diagonally (10 feet) for a total movement of 30 feet.

variantrule.name: Techniques
entries: A number of weapons (mostly martial weapons) have been given one or two innate abilities, which are referred to as Techniques. Any technique is listed as a property on the weapon in question.
You may only use a weapon's technique if you are proficient in that weapon.

If a technique ever calls for a saving throw, the DC is equal to 8 + your proficiency modifier + your Strength modifier. If the weapon in question is a finesse weapon (or another feature/ability grants you the ability to use Dexterity instead of Strength for that weapon), you may use Dexterity instead of Strength when determining your save DC.

variantrule.name: Falling
entries: Falling from a great height is a significant risk for adventurers and their foes. The rule given in the Player's Handbook is simple: at the end of a fall, you take {@dice 1d6} bludgeoning damage for every 10 feet you fell, to a maximum of {@dice 20d6}. You also land {@condition prone}, unless you somehow avoid taking damage from the fall. Here are two rules that expand on that simple rule.

entries.name: Rate of Falling
entries: The rule for falling assumes that a creature immediately drops the entire distance when it falls. But what if a creature is at a high altitude when it falls, perhaps on the back of a {@creature griffon} or on board an {@item airship}? Realistically, a fall from such a height can take more than a few seconds, extending past the end of the turn when the fall occurred. If you'd like high-altitude falls to be properly time-consuming, use the following optional rule.

When you fall from a great height, you instantly descend up to 500 feet. If you're still falling on your next turn, you descend up to 500 feet at the end of that turn. This process continues until the fall ends, either because you hit the ground or the fall is otherwise halted.

entries.name: Flying Creatures and Falling
entries: A flying creature in flight falls if it is knocked {@condition prone}, if its speed is reduced to 0 feet, or if it otherwise loses the ability to move, unless it can hover.

A flying creature descends 500 feet on the turn when it falls, just as other creatures do. But if that creature starts any of its later turns still falling and is {@condition prone}, it can halt the fall on its turn by spending half its flying speed to counter the {@condition prone} condition (as if it were standing up in midair).

variantrule.name: Inspiration
entries: Inspiration is a rule the Dungeon Master can use to reward you for playing your character in a way that's true to his or her personality traits, ideal, bond, and flaw. By using inspiration, you can draw on your personality trait of compassion for the downtrodden to give you an edge in negotiating with the Beggar Prince. Or inspiration can let you call on your bond to the defense of your home village to push past the effect of a spell that has been laid on you.

entries.name: Gaining Inspiration
entries: Your DM can choose to give you inspiration for a variety of reasons. Typically, DMs award it when you play out your personality traits, give in to the drawbacks presented by a flaw or bond, and otherwise portray your character in a compelling way. Your DM will tell you how you can earn inspiration in the game.
You either have inspiration or you don't—you can't stockpile multiple "inspirations" for later use.

entries.name: Using Inspiration
entries: If you have inspiration, you can expend it when you fail an attack roll, saving throw, or ability check. Spending your inspiration allows you to reroll that roll.

entries.name: Inspiration Expiry
entries: If you still have Inspiration when you take a long rest, you lose that Inspiration. At the DM's discretion, if you earned Inspiration very soon before taking a long rest, you may be allowed to carry it over to the next adventuring day, but no more than once.

When a creature and at least one of its allies are adjacent to an enemy and on opposite sides of the enemy's space, they flank that enemy, and each of them has a +2 on melee weapon attack rolls against that enemy.

A creature can't flank an enemy that it can't see. A creature also can't flank while it is {@condition incapacitated}. A Large or larger creature is flanking as long as at least one square or hex of its space qualifies for flanking.

Some creatures have an innate immunity to flanking. These might include particularly large creatures, creatures with no little to no sentience (such as primitive constructs), and creatures with multiple fronts of attack (like a hydra). As flanking was originally an optional rule and not incorporated into monster design, the DM is free to decide when a creature is immune to flanking.

variantrule.name: Mounted Combat
entries: The rules for controlling a mount in combat are replaced with the following.

A controlled mount does not have a turn in combat, and can take no actions, reactions, or bonus actions. During your turn, you may use the mount's movement speed as your own, but you must expend movement all at once: once you start moving, you cannot take any action (even free actions) until you finish moving, and once you end your move you cannot move again during the current turn (even if you would otherwise have movement remaining.
Additionally, if your mount cannot see, you must succeed on a DC 20 Animal Handling check at the start of your turn in order to control it. On a failure, the mount does not move this turn.

entries.name: Design Notes
entries: Mounted Combat has always been very clunky in 5e. The rules as-written have you act on the same initiative, but still on a separate turn, which actually seems like a reasonable trade-off: extra movement in exchange for less flexibility.
This ruleset is intended to mimic that tradeoff in a slightly less clunky way- your movement must occur all at once, but you can do things before and after your move.
Also it removes the ability for mounts to act, as letting mounts take the Dash/Disengage action increases mobility too far. The high base movement speed should probably be sufficient.

variantrule.name: Multiclassing
entries: No multiclassing allowed.

variantrule.name: Optional Class Features
entries: Tasha's Cauldron of Everything introduced a number of variant features for classes. At this point, every variant feature I intend to keep has been fully integrated into their respective classes on this modified copy of 5e, and every other variant feature has been nuked.

In theory, there should be no further ambiguity about what TCE optional class features are allowed. If something still displays as an optional class feature and you are unsure, you can contact me about it.

variantrule.name: Gritty Realism Resting
entries: As I generally prefer long-form adventuring days, we use the Gritty Realism resting variant with some modifications.
This variant uses a short rest of 8 hours and a long rest of 7 days. Additionally, long rests must be taken in a place of relative shelter and safety, with access to food and water.

Furthermore, you may take at most three short rests between long rests. You may, however, spend an hour resting to spend hit dice without counting it as a short rest, though you regain no other resources.
With this variant, you regain all of your hit dice upon completing a long rest, rather than half.
Finally, at the DM's discretion, the duration of a short rest may temporarily shift back to 1 hour in high-pressure environments, like in a dungeon crawl.

entries.name: Costs of Resting
entries: Adventuring comes with associated costs: equipment repair, food, shelter, basic equipment, etc. All minor costs- i.e every cost that isn't assigned a gold value- is abstracted into a single cost of 1 COIN per long rest, per character.

If you are unable or willing to pay the COIN cost in resting, you cannot cure any levels of {@condition exhaustion}, and you gain a level of {@condition unrested|MOD}, which imposes a -1 penalty to your proficiency bonus. The unrested condition can stack indefinitely.

If you are suffering from being {@condition unrested|MOD}, you can spend 1 extra COIN during a long rest to cure 1 level of {@condition unrested|MOD}. You cannot cure more than 1 level of unrested per long rest.

If you are {@i not} suffering from being {@condition unrested|MOD}, you can spend an extra COIN during a long rest to live a luxurious lifestyle, which grants you inspiration at the end of the long rest.
Certain long-term upgrades may increase the cost of resting. For example, a long-term hireling may require payment ever rest, and taking care of a horse might incur an extra cost.

variantrule.name: Sleep
entries: Just as in the real world, D&D characters spend many hours sleeping, most often as part of a long rest. Most monsters also need to sleep. While a creature sleeps, it is subjected to the {@condition unconscious} condition. Here are a few rules that expand on that basic fact.

entries.name: Waking Someone
entries: A creature that is naturally sleeping, as opposed to being in a magically or chemically induced sleep, wakes up if it takes any damage or if someone else uses an action to shake or slap the creature awake. A sudden loud noise—such as yelling, thunder, or a ringing bell—also awakens someone that is sleeping naturally.

Whispers don't disturb sleep, unless a sleeper's passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score is 20 or higher and the whispers are within 10 feet of the sleeper. Speech at a normal volume awakens a sleeper if the environment is otherwise silent (no wind, birdsong, crickets, street sounds, or the like) and the sleeper has a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 15 or higher.

entries.name: Sleeping in Armor
entries: Sleeping or resting in armor is generally impractical. If you attempt to sleep in armor, you must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw; on a failure, you are unable to get a full night of sleep, and are subjected to the penalties laid out in the next section.

entries.name: Going without Sleep
entries: Every adventurer needs their sleep.
Whenever you end a 24-hour period without getting a full night's worth of sleep, you must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

It becomes harder to fight off {@condition exhaustion} if you repeatedly attempt to stay up. After the first 24 hours, the DC increases by 5 for each 24-hour period without a full night of sleep. The DC does not reset to 10 until you finish a long rest.

variantrule.name: Spellcasting
entries: This section expands on the spellcasting rules presented in the Player's Handbook and the Dungeon Master's Guide, providing clarifications and new options. See also {@variantrule Bonus Action Spells|MOD} and {@variantrule Spell Template Placement|MOD}.

entries.name: Perceiving a Caster at Work
entries: Many spells create obvious effects: explosions of fire, walls of ice, teleportation, and the like. Other spells, such as charm person, display no visible, audible, or otherwise perceptible sign of their effects, and could easily go unnoticed by someone unaffected by them. As noted in the Player's Handbook, you normally don't know that a spell has been cast unless the spell produces a noticeable effect.

But what about the act of casting a spell? Is it possible for someone to perceive that a spell is being cast in their presence? To be perceptible, the casting of a spell must involve a verbal or somatic component.

If the need for a spell's components has been removed by a special ability, such as the sorcerer's Subtle Spell feature or the Innate Spellcasting trait possessed by many creatures, the casting of the spell is imperceptible. If an imperceptible casting results in a perceptible effect, it may be impossible to determine who the effect originated from, though in other circumstances it is more obvious. (For example, an imperceptibly cast illusion spell may have no obvious source, but a {@spell scorching ray} or {@spell fireball} has a visible effect that emenates from its source.)

entries.name: Identifying a Spell
entries: Generally, you may identify any spell as it is being cast as long as it is perceptible and of a level you can cast or lower. There may be occasional exceptions if a spell is particularly obscure, as per a mage casting spells that would not normally be available to players.

Identifying spells {@i after} they are cast is more difficult. If you did not see the original casting of the spell, you must succeed on an Intelligence (Arcana) check to identify the spell or the nature of the magic, or use an {@spell identify} spell.
You may also assume that NPC spellcasters obey these rules as well, for the purpose of spells such as Counterspell.

entries.name: Invalid Spell Targets
entries: A spell specifies what a caster can target with it: any type of creature, a creature of a certain type (humanoid or beast, for instance), an object, an area, the caster, or something else. But what happens if a spell targets something that isn't a valid target? For example, someone might cast {@spell charm person} on a creature believed to be a humanoid, not knowing that the target is in fact a vampire. If this issue comes up, handle it using the following rule.

If you cast a spell on someone or something that can't be affected by the spell, nothing happens to that target, but if you used a spell slot to cast the spell, the slot is still expended. If the spell normally has no effect on a target that succeeds on a saving throw, the invalid target appears to have succeeded on its saving throw, even though it didn't attempt one (giving no hint that the creature is in fact an invalid target). Otherwise, you perceive that the spell did nothing to the target.

variantrule.name: Areas of Effect on a Grid
entries: Several rules follow for setting Areas of Effect on a battlemap.

Choose an {@b intersection of squares as the point of origin} of an area of effect, then follow the rules for that kind of area as normal (see the "Areas of Effect" section in chapter 10 of the Player's Handbook). If an area of effect covers at least half a square, it affects that square.

If a creature is Large or larger, an area-of-effect ability must cover half or more of the creature's space to have full effect. If it covers less than half of the creature's space, the creature has advantage on saving throws against the effect. If it covers less than 1/4th of the creature's space, then it has no effect.

variantrule.name: Blacksmiths and Craftsmen
entries: In the course of adventuring, warriors often seek the services of blacksmiths and craftsmen to forge weapons, armor, and other items to arm themselves. Of course, not all smiths are created equal- some are content working brass in the local village forge, while others are renowned across the land. Smiths and craftsmen can broadly be grouped into three tiers:

entries.name: Local
entries: A local smith or craftsman can be found pretty much anywhere. Their services are not particularly in demand, and they can be commissioned fairly easily, although their talent is limited and they have access to only meagre resources. A village blacksmith or a town fletcher is probably a local smith.

entries.name: Expert
entries: An expert smith is is renowned and respected in their craft, with access to considerable resources and aid. They are usually only found in capital cities and other significant population centers. Their work is often in-demand and their prices high, but their skill is worth it.

entries.name: Legendary
entries: A legendary smith is a true master of their craft. Some can be found in city centers, but others have the luxury of isolating themselves on far-off islands or in mountainside retreats, having accumulated sufficient resources to dedicate themselves fully to their craft, away from the constant demands of commercial sites.

Legendary smiths are rare, extremely talented, and extraordinarily hard to commission. Aside from being in high demand, they tend to be rather picky about the jobs they take. They may require a quest to be completed, or a gift of a rare material or item, before they even consider taking on a job.

variantrule.name: FORGE
entries: The blade of a guardsman is quite different from the blade of a warrior. A guard carries a sword as a symbol of authority, and a good guardsman unsheathes the blade rarely. But a warrior often meets foes who cannot be reasoned with, and must entrust their lives to their weapons on a regular basis. Therefore, though a standard brass blade is quite sufficient for a watchman, the adventurer often seeks a blade more finely tuned for their specific purpose.

The FORGE system introduces a number of new upgrades that may be applied to mundane weapons, to enhance them with greater slaying power and give martials an expanded range of tactical options. At this point in time, these upgrades can only be applied to melee weapons.
First, a few relevant terms are defined below:

entries.name: Bonus Damage
entries: Some abilities tell you to add bonus damage to an attack's damage. Bonus damage is equal to a single roll of the weapon's damage (for example, a greatsword would have a bonus damage of 2d6. A normal greatsword attack deals 2d6 + STR damage, but if you are told to add bonus damage, it becomes 4d6 + STR).

Bonus damage cannot be stacked from the same source, but it may be stacked from different sources- for example, you might add bonus damage from both the weapon's material and due to an upgrade of the weapon. Some upgrades may have you add multiple bonus damage dice.

The damage type of the bonus damage is determined by the weapon's material. If there is no special material, or the material lists no bonus damage type, then the bonus damage is the same damage type as the weapon.

entries.name: Pierce
entries: If a weapon {@i pierces} a creature, then it ignores any resistances (but not immunities) the creature has against the weapon's base damage type and the weapon's bonus damage type.

entries.name: Rend
entries: If a weapon {@i rends} a creature, then it both {@i pierces} them and deals bonus damage.

entries.name: Upscale
entries: If you are told to upscale a weapon's damage dice, increment it by one notch: damage dice go from {@dice 1d1} < {@dice 1d4} < {@dice 1d6} < {@dice 1d8} < {@dice 1d10} < {@dice 1d12} < {@dice 2d6}. To downscale a damage dice, simply make it one increment smaller. For example, a upscaled dagger would become a 1d6 weapon, while a downscaled dagger would do a measly 1 damage.
You cannot take any that would reduce your damage die below a 1. You {@i can} take an upgrade that upscales your die above a 2d6, but it does not modify the dice further.

entries.name: Materials
entries: Most people are familiar with silver-coated weapons, rumored to be particularly, effective at slaying monsters, but an experienced warrior knows that there is a far greater variety of {@filter materials |items|source=mod|property=material} that might be applied to a blade.

Some materials are harder to work with than others, and may require an expert or a legendary smith to work. Materials may be applied to magic weapons, but at a drastically increased cost and requiring the service of a legendary smith. If the material in question is rare or restricted, you may be required to provide the material in addition to the cost.
You must be proficient in a weapon to benefit from a material applied to it.

entries.name: Upgrades
entries: Many longtime warriors often find it useful to customize their weapons to better suit their fighting style. Up to three {@filter  upgrades|items|source=mod|property=upgrade} can be applied to a single weapon.

The first upgrade to a weapon costs 3 COIN to apply; the next costs 7 COIN and requires the service of an expert smith, and the last upgrade costs a whopping 12 COIN and requires a legendary craftsman.
A magic item can bear only one upgrade, requires a legendary smith to add, and costs 12 COIN to augment.
In addition, many upgrades have their own restrictions on what weapons they can be applied to. You may encounter opportunities to add more unique upgrades to your weapons as you travel.
You must be proficient with a weapon to benefit from any upgrade it possesses.
You may also wish to review {@variantrule blacksmiths and craftsmen} for information on expert and legendary smiths.

variantrule.name: COIN
entries: 5e economy has traditionally been absolutely broken, and therefore ignored- specifically, it has always been unclear how much money players are supposed to have and there's also been nothing to buy. However, I think there is some value in having a simple, functioning economy, with the ability to spend money to improve your equipment and advance your goals, so this COIN system is a rework of the gold system to simplify things down and create a currency that is more easily tracked, awarded, and is more useful to spend.

entries.name: Abstraction
entries: COIN abstracts down the currency system away from gold and silver and platinum and converts everything into a unit of value that we will just call COIN. The idea is essentially stolen from Blades in the Dark.

1 COIN is worth significantly more than 1 gp. It is assumed that adventurers generally exist beyond the life of quibbling over silver and copper- for the average adventurer, dropping a couple gold on a purchase is barely even worth paying attention to. As such, most minor purchases have been abstracted away to nothing- most adventuring gear, like rope, is now functionally free. The COIN is certainly not the baseline unit of money in-universe, but it serves as an abstraction for the smallest unit of money an adventurer should really care about.

Adventurers are expected to earn COIN through significant deeds. Most mundane jobs won't earn you a significant amount of money (with a few exceptions, as per some backgrounds), and therefore won't even get you 1 COIN worth of value. Certainly haggling over inn rooms won't save you anything meaningful. Going out and killing a monster terrorizing the village, or blackmailing a rich politician, are deeds that will earn you some decent COIN.

The COIN system works hand-in-hand with the {@variantrule STASH} system, which is a simplified inventory system that limits characters to a flat number of inventory slots (so even though most adventuring gear is functionally free, you cannot just carry an infinite amount of it.)

entries.name: Uses for COIN
entries: The first and primary use of COIN is the maintenance of your character, your party, and associated belongings. All associated costs of adventuring- housing, food, mundane ammunition, weapon and armor repairs, simple equipment, etc, are not things to be tracked individually, but do incur a cost. Under the COIN system, all minor costs are abstracted into a single cost of 1 COIN per character every time you take a long rest. See {@variantrule Gritty Realism Resting} for details.

The other major use for COIN is to purchase useful items. See in particular {@variantrule FORGE} for details on the new weapon upgrade system, which martials should take advantage of. You might also look at the items page for a few new mundane items that have been added. Spellcasters of course still have to invest in certain costly components for their spells. Though there are no true magic item shops in Sorspecto, the underground black market {@i does} do a healthy trade in such relics.
And of course COIN greases the wheels of the world. A well placed 'investment' can open doors or buy valuable information. It's no secret that big spenders get priority treatment.

entries.name: Meta: Implementation of COIN on 5e.tools
entries: In 5e.tools, there's no way for me to visually change costs into COIN. In places where cost is listed, like in the Items page, you should assume that the listed price is in COIN rather than gp- for example, a {@item light crossbow} is listed as costing 1 gp, which really means it costs 1 COIN.

If an item seems to have a cost disproportionate to its value, it may be because I forgot to convert the price into COIN. Please let me know if this happens. At this point in time, I should have converted anything on the Items page and the Spells page; things in any other section may have been missed.

variantrule.name: STASH
entries: The 5e inventory has been defunct for a long time- generally, players are given free reign to carry around whatever they want, which is primary balanced by the fact that (non-magic) items in 5e are generally useless. It's basically the skyrim system. The following inventory rules are made to simplify the inventory system and make it easier to track, which is intended to work in conjunction with more useful weapons and items and more readily purchasable consumables.

entries.name: Abstraction
entries: The STASH system is pretty simple. You have a number of inventory slots equal to 8 + your Strength modifier. Most items take 1 slot, particularly large items may take more (2-3). Armor and worn equipment don't count toward your inventory slots while they are worn.
Generally, any tiny item (items that are small enough that you could hold a handful of them- like chalk, candles, or rings) can be carried freely. Held COIN does not consume inventory slots.

entries.name: Preparation Slots
entries: When you complete a long rest in a town, city, or other populated area, you can allocate some of your inventory slots to be Preparation Slots. These slots serve as a flexible inventory- at any point before you complete another long rest, you can {@i retroactively} decide what that slot contains. For example, you can retroactively decide that you had brought along a grappling hook, or a rope, by using one of your preparation slots.

Once you declare what is in a preparation slot, it reverts to a regular slot containing that item. You can only fill preparation slots with items that have negligible cost and are readily available for sale. A preparation slot is considered to be filled.
You can have a number of Preparation slots equal to your Intelligence modifier.

entries.name: Managing your STASH
entries: This inventory system is a lot {@i tighter} than 5e's default. Don't be afraid to throw items away when you no longer need them- you can always salvage things from the environment anyway.

In particular, holding on to consumables overlong is basically equivalent to wasting an inventory slot- same with carrying too many backup weapons. Hoarding too much will result in having no slots to carry any new items with.

Note that although abstract COIN does not take up inventory slots, physical treasure does. All treasure found on expeditions and quests needs to be hauled back to town to be sold and converted into useful currency- so you'd better save enough inventory slots to transport your loot.

entries.name: Meta: Implementation of STASH on 5e.tools
entries: There's no way for me to set things as taking up slots rather than weight on 5e.tools. Assume that for all {@i mundane} items, their weight in pounds is the number of slots they take up. (All mundane items {@i should} have been adjusted to this metric, although I may have missed some.) Magic items will need their weight to be configured upon import, as I am not going to manually set the weight of every possible magic item. As a rule of thumb, most items take 1 slot, but heavy and two-handed items (and any similarly large, heavy item) take 2 slots. I struggle to think of many scenarios where you would get larger items (besides armor, perhaps).

variantrule.name: GRIM
entries: It's no secret that death saves in 5e are a little bit weird: a PC left on the ground is either ignored, in which case they bounce back up almost immediately after a {@spell healing word}, or they get double-tapped and murdered before anybody has a chance to intervene. It's a system that's often entirely dependent on the DM's mercy, and is basically held up by the DM creating reasons that the enemy doesn't just finish off a downed PC.
The following system revision, haphazardly called GRIM, is intended to give dying PCs a little more agency in their deaths while removing the factor of DM mercy from the equation.
