Note that this system is pretty heavily experimental. If I feel like it's performing poorly, I may revoke it during a campaign.

entries.name: Negative Hit Points
entries: Hit points are now allowed to go negative, to a certain point. If a single instance of damage brings your hit points below 0, your hit points go negative. However, if your hit points are already 0 or negative, all subsequent hits do not decrease your hit points further; instead, they trigger death saving throws.

For example, if you have 4 hit points and a goblin stabs you for 10 damage, your hit points go to -6 rather than 0. If they stab you again, your hit points do not change, but you must make a death saving throw (detailed later). If you heal back to 2 hit points, getting attacked again could drop your hit points negative again.
If you complete a short rest, your hit points are set to 1 if they were 0 or below. This happens before you recieve any healing from hit dice.

entries.name: Bleeding Out
entries: Going to 0 hit points (or lower) no longer knocks you unconscious. Instead, you begin {@condition bleeding out|MOD}. Unlike in 5e, you are {@i not} unconscious or incapacitated while bleeding out, and you can continue to take actions under some constraints (see the {@condition bleeding out|MOD} condition).

entries.name: Recovering
entries: Note that you don't stop bleeding out until you return to positive hit points, which requires you to first heal above any negative hit points you have. This means that small amounts of healing are less useful if you're at very negative hit points. Also, all healing now has value when you're at positive hit points- even if the healing doesn't prevent you from getting knocked below 0 in the next hit, it means your hit points will be less negative, putting you at less risk.

entries.name: Death Saves
entries: If you take damage while you are {@condition bleeding out}, you must make a death saving throw with a DC equal to 5 or half the damage taken (whichever is higher). Death saves are still made with a +0 modifier by default. Rolling a natural 1 on a death save still causes 2 failures. Rolling a natural 20 restores 2d8 hit points to you (although you continue bleeding out if your hit points are still below 0).

You can no longer 'stabilize'; succeeding on death saves does nothing. You only stop making death saves if you fail 3 death saves (see "Mortality", below) or if you stop bleeding out (i.e are healed above 0 hit points). Once you stop bleeding out, your death saves reset to 0 failures.

Temporary hit points don't stop you from bleeding out; however, any damage absorbed by temporary hit points is not counted in the death save DC calculation. (If you have 6 temp hp and you take 20 damage, you would only need to succeed on a DC 7 death saving throw rather than a DC 10). You still must make a death saving throw even if all damage taken is absorbed by your temporary hit points.

entries.name: Mortality
entries: Heroes tend to be resilient- even a mortal blow doesn't necessarily mean certain death. If you fail 3 (or more) death saving throws, you must roll a single d6 and reference the below table to determine what happens.

entries.caption: Mortality Result
rows: You die.

Your character survives, but suffers a severe lingering injury and is removed from the encounter. Resurrection magic can return your character back to functioning form; otherwise, they cannot meaningfully contribute until they spend at least an hour recovering.

Your character survives without lasting harm, though they are removed from the encounter. Resurrection magic can return your character back to functioning form; otherwise, they cannot meaningfully contribute until they spend at least an hour recovering.

entries: A character knocked out of the fight remains at negative hit points when they recover, and is still {@condition bleeding out} until they return to positive hit points. If time is not urgent, an easy way to do this is to take a short rest (see above).
{@variantrule Lingering Injuries|MOD} has the rolltables and rule outline for lingering injuries.

Note that instakill effects (like Disintegrate) subvert the Mortality roll, and still result in immediate death. Moreover, some enemies may have the Lethal ability, which ignores the Mortality roll entirely.

entries.name: Design Notes
entries: There's a certain dilemma when it comes to death in 5e- namely that although we want the risk of death to be present in difficult combats, we also don't {@i really} want player characters to die (too often)- frequent death messes with the story, disrupts roleplay, cuts off plot threads, and trivializes death.

Oftentimes we compensate by using stakes that don't involve PC death- losing doesn't mean you {@i die} but rather you fail in an important objective. This isn't universally applicable, however, and still runs into the problem that 5e doesn't have a solid failstate in combat other than the TPK (or at least the "everybody is unconscious" state, which on average kills about half the party anyway).

So the mortality system is intended to first allow for a risk of death, without relying on DM mercy, but also to keep death from being too common. A 1/6 chance of dying at 3 death saves isn't that big, but it's large enough that it's a very real possibility. Most of the time, instead of dying, a character suffers a lingering wound, which requires time and care to heal.

This system also works to avoid players lying on the ground unconscious, and keeps them in the battle- which means they can keep helping, but also means they're at greater risk. This means that although players will stay conscious longer, they're also more susceptible to being knocked out of the battle entirely, as enemies will continue attacking them. This is {@i probably} okay- in the worst case it's not that different from being stabbed to death while unconscious anyway.

Negative hit points is a ruleset that will need to be watched carefully. In theory, the goal is to incentivize healing players who are at low hit points to give them a 'buffer' against negative hp, and to prevent low amounts of healing from being able to easily reset death saves (which is a large reason why 5e death saves are so non-threatening). In practice, negative hp may become too negative to heal (i.e if a low hp player endures a full dragon's breath), given 5e's rather conservative approach toward healing. We'll see if it becomes a problem.

variantrule.name: Lingering Injuries
entries: Adventuring is a dangerous business. Most adventurers are resilient enough to survive a few scrapes with death, but rarely without enduring some lasting harm along the way.

The following tables detail injuries you might receive while adventuring. These injuries are given as part of the {@variantrule GRIM} system, so you only receive them if you fail three death saves and are forced to make a Mortality roll.

If you are told to roll for a lingering injury, roll on the table corresponding to the damage type that caused you to fail your last death save. If there was more than 1 damage type involved, the DM chooses which one applies. (If the DM is ambivalent, they can simply choose whichever one did more damage.)

entries.name: Treatment
entries: Adventurers are adaptable and hardy. Many injuries can be recovered from through simple time and care, perhaps augmented with some healing magic. More severe injuries may require surgery- either by one of your stalwart companions, or, if you don't trust the barbarian with delicate instruments, by a city surgeon.

Many of the listed injuries can be treated with an ability check over a short or long rest. Only one ability check can be made over these rests- it's assumed that only one doctor can be operating on the patient at once, and that the treatment occupies much of the rest's time. Some injuries require Surgeries, which are much more specialized operations that benefit from proficiency in the {@item Surgeon's Tools|MOD}. A Surgery check can be repeated, but every check causes the patient to lose a portion of their maximum hit points, so be careful.

Even if treatment fails and an injury becomes permanent, don't fret- even a permanent injury may be adapted to and worked around. Prosthetics can be acquired and custom weapons can be made to accomodate for the effects of long-lasting injuries, though they may require some time to get used to.

entries.name: Reference
entries: A few important terms & broad info used when describing injuries.

entries.name: Nonfunctional & Missing
entries: {@b Nonfunctional} describes a limb or sense that has been damaged to the point where it ceases to function- a broken leg or a hand in the early stages of frostbite, for example.
{@b Missing} describes a limb or sense that is permanently detached or destroyed. A severed arm or leg is the classic example.
{@b Nonfunctional} and {@b Missing} limbs/senses have essentially the same effects (see below), but may differ in their treatment.

entries.name: Effects of Nonfunctional and Missing Limbs

entries.caption: Nonfunctional/Missing Eyes
rows: One Eye
You have disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight and on ranged attack rolls.
Both Eyes
You are {@condition blinded}.

entries.caption: Nonfunctional/Missing Ears
rows: One Ear
You have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.
Both Eyes
You are {@condition deafened}.

entries.caption: Nonfunctional/Missing Limbs
rows: One hand/arm

You can no longer hold anything with two hands, and you can only hold a single object at a time. You have disadvantage on Strength and Dexterity based ability checks that would normally require the use of both arms (such as a Strength [Athletics] ability check made to climb, or a Dexterity ability check made to use thieves' tools). A character may be able to eliminate these penalties over time through practice and training.
Both hands/arms
You can no longer hold anything. You automatically fail any ability check that normally requires the use of both arms.
One foot/leg

You require assistive equipment to walk, such as a cane, crutches, or a prosthesis. Without this equipment, your speed is halved and you fall {@condition prone} after using the {@action Dash} action. You have disadvantage on Dexterity checks made to balance.
Both feet/leg
You require the use of assistive equipment to move, such as a wheelchair. Without this equipment, your speed is 10 feet, you are constantly {@condition prone}, and you cannot get up from being prone.

entries.caption: Nonfunctional/Missing Misc
rows: Smell
You cannot smell. You automatically fail any ability check that requires smell.
Taste
You cannot taste. You automatically fail any ability check that requires taste.
Voice

You cannot speak. You automatically fail any ability check that requires the use of your voice. You cannot use your voice to provide the verbal component of spells. You have disadvantage on Charisma ability checks unless you are proficient in gestural language or are communicating telepathically.

variantrule.name: Tool Proficiencies
entries: Tool proficiencies have been somewhat overhauled. A lot of tools were thrown out, and those that remained have been given more specific but generally reliably useful cases.
Accordingly, backgrounds have mostly been stripped of tool proficiencies.

From an outside perspective, it's useful to remember that tool proficiencies generally represent an {@i adventurer's} understanding of a particular craft. An adventurer isn't ever going to be a master craftsman, because they're far too busy getting themselves nearly killed in the field, but they might pick up proficiency in alchemy supplies so they can brew themselves a few healing potions, though they're unlikely to be able to do more advanced alchemy without retiring and focusing their efforts.
A list of available tool proficiencies are listed below.
Most artisan tools have been removed. They're basically backstory features anyway.

variantrule.name: Using Creature Statblocks for Players
entries: Sometimes, a feature will have you summon a creature to the field (such as the various Summon X spells), or will ask you to pick from a range of statblocks in some way (such as the {@spell Polymorph|MOD} spell or a druid's Wildshape.)
If you are ever told to select from a range of creatures, assume you are limited to creatures included in the Monster Manual.

Additionally, you must prepare these abilities ahead of time- if you have a set statblock, you must let me know what it is so it can be imported into Foundry, and if you select from a range of statblocks, you should choose a selection of statblocks to cover your basic use cases so they can be pre-imported into Foundry.
Addendum: If a Monster Manual statblock is reprinted in Mordenkainen Presents: Monsters of the Multiverse, you should still use the original Monster Manual statblock.

variantrule.name: Bonus Action Spells
entries: The rules disallow you to cast a bonus action spell and a leveled spell in the same turn. This is a little complicated, so the simpler rule we use is as follows:
You can only cast 1 leveled spell per turn, excluding reaction spells.

variantrule.name: Spell Template Placement
entries: Not a homebrew rule, but a slightly obscure DMG rule. When placing a template that targets a point in space, the point of origin (as determined by Foundry) must be at an intersection of squares or hexes (that is, a corner).
This doesn't affect spells that originate from the self, like Lightning Bolt, Thunderwave, most cone spells, Spiritual Gardians, etc. It does affect things like Fireball, Moonbeam, etc.

Technically this is a slight deviation in that the point of origin for cubes is changed, but this is probably OK, in that Foundry's origin functions better than the DMG's origin when working on a grid.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Acid
table.caption: Acid Injury
rows: {@b Ocular Corrosion.} Acid has splashed over both of your eyes. You are blinded and both your eyes are {@b nonfunctional}. If you do not receive surgery within 30 minutes your vision will be permanently missing. Requires a DC 20 Surgery to treat.

{@b Dissolved Limb.} Acid coats one of your limbs, and you hear the sizzle as it starts to dissolve. This limb is {@b nonfunctional}; if you do not recieve surgery within 1 hour, the limb dissolves away and is {@b missing}. Requires a DC 20 Surgery to treat.

{@bold Vocal Cord Damage} The acid's caustic fumes have wreaked havoc on your vocal cords. Your voice is nonfunctional and you are {@condition silenced}. If you do not receive treatment within 30 minutes it will be permanently missing. (DC 17 Surgery)

{@bold Dissolved Magic.} The acid has eaten into the essence of one of your magic items, expelling its arcane energy and rendering it mundane. One random magic item on your person (prioritizing attuned, worn, and wielded items) loses its magic. A master craftsman can potentially restore the item. A legendary or artifact item is instead suppressed for 1d4 long rests.

{@bold Corroded Armor.} Your armor takes a -3 penalty to the AC it provides until repaired. If its base AC is reduced to 10 or lower, it is destroyed. (If your armor is magical, it cannot be destroyed by this injury, but is rendered useless if brought below 10 base AC until repaired). If you are wearing no armor, treat this result as a 9.

{@bold Corroded Weapon.} The acid eats away at your weapon or spellcasting focus. Whatever weapon or focus you are wielding takes a -3 penalty to all attack rolls, damage rolls, and saving throw DCs (for spellcasting foci).

{@bold Caustic Burn.} The acid has left you with a painful burn. You take 1 point of acid damage for every 5 feet you move while in initative, or while exerting yourself (i.e running away). A DC 16 Medicine check made over a short rest ends this effect.
{@bold Scaly Scar.} The acid injury has resulted in a gnarled and scaly scar.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Bludgeoning
table.caption: Bludgeoning Injury
rows: {@b Ruptured Eardrum.} A violent impact to the side of your head causes one of your eardrums to rupture, rendering the ear {@b nonfunctional}. If not treated within 24 hours, it is permanently {@b missing}. Treat with a DC 20 Surgery.
{@b Crushed Limb.} One of your limbs is crushed to the point of uselessness and is permanently {@b nonfunctional}. It will not regain functionality without treatment. Treat with a DC 23 Surgery.

{@bold Serious Concussion.} A strike to your head has left you with dizziness, nausea, and a lingering headache. You have disadvantage on mental ability checks and Concentration saving throws. Every time you fail a mental saving throw, there is a 50% chance you are {@condition stunned} until the end of your next turn. This concussion lingers for 1d3 long rests. Treating it with a DC 20 Medicine check reduces the duration of this injury by 1d2 long rests.
{@bold Broken Limb.} One of your limbs is broken, rendering it {@b nonfunctional} for 1d3 long rests. Treating it with a DC 15 Medicine check over a short rest reduces the duration by 1d2 long rests.

{@bold Mild Concussion.} You have disadvantage on mental ability checks and Concentration saving throws. This injury lasts for 1d2 long rests, and can be treated with a DC 15 Medicine check over a short rest.
{@bold Cracked Rib.} One or more of your ribs is cracked. Any time you make an Athletics or Acrobatics check, you take 1d8 bludgeoning damage. This injury resolves on its own after 1d2 long rests.
{@bold Serious Bruise.} Your entire body aches and you are left with some extensive ugly bruises. You have disadvantage on Persuasion checks. These bruises heal on their own after 1d2 long rests.
{@bold Minor Bruise.} You are left with a lingering but harmless bruise.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Cold
table.caption: Cold Injury
rows: {@b Frozen Limb.} One of your limbs is frozen solid, and is essentially {@b nonfunctional}. The limb heals automatically if you spend a long rest warming it. However, if you are struck by a critical hit before then, the limb shatters and is {@b missing}.

{@b Frozen Voice.} You've breathed in so many cold vapors that your throat is beginning to freeze solid. You have disadvantage on Persuasion, Deception, and Intimidation checks that involve speaking, and whenever you cast a spell with a Verbal component, there is a 50% chance that it fails, wasting the action. If treated with a DC 20 Medicine check, it heals after a long rest. If left untreated, there is a 50% chance that the injury heals on its own after a long rest, and a 50% chance that the injury progresses further, rendering your vocal cords permanently {@b nonfunctional}.
{@bold Pervasive Cold.} You are under the effects of the {@spell slow} spell until you spend a long rest slowly rewarming yourself.

{@bold Weakened Constitution.} The cold has weakened your body, leaving you weak and frail. Lose {@dice 1d4} from your Constitution score, to a minimum of 1. Every time you complete a long rest, your Constitution score heals by 1.

{@bold Slowed Reflexes.} The cold has seeped into your nerves, causing you to become slow and sluggish. You have disadvantage on initiative checks and Dexterity saving throws. Treat with a DC 15 Medicine check over a long rest.
{@b Frost Nipped Toes.} Your feet are frozen over. You cannot take the {@action Dash} action until treated. Treat with a DC 18 Medicine check over a short rest.

{@bold Shivers.} Your hands shake uncontrollably and your voice quavers as you speak. You have disadvantage on checks that involve fine manipulation of objects, as well as Persuasion, Deception, and Intimidation checks.
{@bold Frozen Scar.} You are left with a pale, blue-tinged scar.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Fire
table.caption: Fire Injury
rows: {@b Third Degree Burn.} You have a deep burn penetrating into your skin, resulting in a cracked, red wound. While in initiative or exerting yourself, you take 1 fire damage for every 5 feet of movement. In addition, you take 1d4 fire damage every time you take an action or bonus action. This injury lasts 1d2 long rests. A DC 16 Medicine check made over a long rest reduces the duration by 1 long rest.

{@b Airway Burn.} You've inhaled the scorching air around you and it burns a path straight down to your lungs. Your sense of taste and smell are {@b nonfunctional} and if not treated within 24 hours will be permanently {@b missing}. Treat with a DC20 Surgery.

{@bold Welded Armor.} Your armor half-melts in the heat and partially melds into your skin. Until fixed, you cannot doff your armor, and your armor cannot undergo any sort of modification or improvement until it is removed. Sleeping in medium or heavy armor is uncomfortable- see {@variantrule Sleeping in Armor} If you are not wearing armor, reroll the injury.
{@bold Heat Stroke.} You gain two levels of {@condition exhaustion}, which can be cured as normal.

{@bold Second Degree Burn.} Your skin bubbles and blisters. While in initiative or exerting yourself, you take 1 fire damage for every 5 feet of movement. This injury lasts 1d2 long rests. A DC 12 Medicine check made over a long rest reduces the duration by 1 long rest.

{@bold Disfiguring Scars.} A large burn scar disfigures your face, imposing disadvantage to Persuasion checks but granting you advantage on Intimidation checks. The scar can be treated by a DC 15 Surgery administered within 24 hours; if successful, this injury instead becomes a Mild Burn (11-12).
{@bold Heat Exhaustion.} You gain one level of {@condition exhaustion}, which can be cured as normal.
{@bold Mild Burn.} You've been left with a disfiguring but otherwise harmless patch of burnt skin.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Force
table.caption: Force Injury
rows: {@b Third Eye Blinded.} Something vitla, yet intangible within you falls deathly silent. You feel... disconnected. You lose the ability to communicate telepathically, and all magical communication that specifically targets you fails (such as the {@spell message}, {@spell sending}, and {@spell telepathic bond} spells. Your mind cannot be magically read.

{@b Magical Anathema.} You shake your head from the force of the arcane blow and... it's gone- the knowledge, that is, not your head. You lose the ability to cast your most recently cast spell permanently. You can never cast this spell again by any means (including class features, racial traits, or magical items). If your class allows you to replace spells on your spell list when leveling up, you may still replace this spell normally.
{@bold Pertinax Machina.} Your spells struggle to take and always seem like they need a little something extra. Any spell with material component cost requires double that cost to cast.

{@bold Null Arcana.} As the arcane energy strikes you, something in you sputters and fizzles. Every spell you cast has a 50% chance of failure, wasting the action and slot. This lasts for 1d3 long rests.

{@bold Ligo Secare.} You feel the abrupt and disconcerting recoin of a severed connection. You lose attunement to all items you are currently attuned to, and you cannot attune to anything until you complet 1d2 long rests.

{@bold Mana Syphon.} You feel the energy suck away your arcan eessence, leaving you with a lingering feeling of emptiness. Two of your highest level spell slots are harmlessly expended, and cannot be regained for {@dice 1d4} long rests. A DC 18 Arcana check made over a short rest can reduce the duration by {@dice 1d2} long rests.

{@bold Null Scola.} You feel the magic pulse and resonate with the arcane residue that clings to you from the last spell you cast. There's a searing feeling deep in your mind. You lose the ability to cast spells from the same school of magic as the most recent spell you've cast for {@dice 1d4} long rests.
{@bold Mana Burn.} You are left with a dimly glowing but otherwise harmless magical scar that emits wisps of arcane energy.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Lightning
table.caption: Lightning Injury
rows: {@b Arrythmia.} Electricity surges into the core of your being, causing your heart to stutter. It is far more difficult for you to handle physical activity without becoming greatly fatigued. Whenever you gain exhaustion, you take one additional level. Treat with a DC 22 Surgery.

{@b Heart Palpitations.} Shocked through the heart, and you're to blame... Any time you are {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}, you must succeed on a DC 20 Constitution saving throw or gain 1 level of Exhaustion. Treat with a DC 22 Surgery.

{@bold Personality Shift.} Your brain is damaged by the electrical surge, and you're not acting like yourself. You either gain a new {@i flaw}, or an existing flaw intensifies. DC 25 Surgery to treat.
{@bold Muscle Avulsion.} Your muscle has contracted so strongly that it has been torn free of the bone. One of your limbs is {@b nonfunctional} until treated with a DC20 Surgery.

{@bold Muscle Spasms.} Your muscles twitch in reptitive patterns and you have difficulty coordinating your movement. You have disadvantage on all Dexterity attacks, checks, and saves for 1d4 long rests. Treat with a DC 15 Medicine check to reduce duration by 1d2.
{@bold Numbed Nerves.} Your nerves are shot and you feel numb. You cannot take reactions. Treat with a DC 14 Medicine check over a short rest.

{@bold Lightning Rod.} Your skin feels oddly conductive. Whenever another creature takes lightning damage within 5 feet of you, you take an equal amount of lightning damage. Treat with a DC 17 Medicine check over a long rest.
{@bold Lictenburg Figure.} You are left with a scar resembling lightning, running along the path the current took through your body.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Piercing
table.caption: Piercing Injury
rows: {@b Gouged Eye.} You've taken heavy damage directly to one of your eyes. Your eye is {@b nonfunctional}. If untreated within 8 hours, your vision will be beyond saving and considered {@b missing} Treat with a DC 20 Surgery.

{@b Sharp Residue.} The triggering attack has left something buried in your body- an arrowhead, a tooth, a shard from a sword, perhaps. You can feel it cutting inside you. Any time you use a action, bonus action, and movement on the same turn, you are incapacitated until the end of your next turn. Treat with a DC 19 Surgery.

{@bold Infection.} The wound closes easily, but the attack has left an insidious contamination deep inside. At the end of every long rest, you lose maximum hit points equal to two rolls of your class's hit die. If this effect reduces your hit points to 0, you die. You can cure the infection by making a DC 22 Constitution saving throw or a DC 17 Medicine check over a long rest, but this only treats the infection, not the max hit point reduction.

{@bold Perforated Gut.} You've taken a nasty wound in the gut, and it's only a matter of time until it turns septic. you are {@condition poisoned}. Every 24 hours, you gain 1 level of {@condition exhaustion}. This level of exhaustion cannot be removed by nonmagical means. A DC 21 Surgery will treat the wound, and any effect that cures disease can remove 1 level of exhaustion. The poisoned condition cannot be cured until the infection is treated.

{@bold Punctured Leg.} The attack sinks into the meat of your leg. It's probably not serious, but the pain makes you treat your leg gingerly. Your speed is reduced by 10 feet. Treat with a DC 14 Medicine check over a long rest.

{@bold Ran Through.} The attack went in one end and out the other. It's missed your vitals, but you can still feel the pain every time you move. All bonus actions now require a full action instead. Treat with a DC 15 Medicine check over a long rest.

{@bold Punctured Lung.} The wound makes it past your ribs and into your lung. You amek Strength (Athletics) and Dexterity (Acrobatics) checks at disadvantage for 1d2 long rests. Treat with a DC 15 Medicine check over a short rest, which reduces the duration by 1 long rest.
{@bold Gnarled Scar.} You are left with a raised, gnarled scar.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Poison
table.caption: Poison Injury
rows: {@b Anemic.} When the poison has run its course, you are left with a lingering weakness. Your carrying capacity is reduced by 3 slots.
{@b Cyanotic.} Your lips turn blue, you're out of breath, and you feel like you can't suck in enough air no matter how hard you try. You suffer three levels of {@condition exhaustion}.

{@bold Numbed Senses.} The poison wreaks havoc on your body. Either your sense of smell or taste (determined randomly) is {@b nonfunctional}. Treat with a DC 15 Survival check over a long rest- on a failure, the sense becomes permanently {@b missing}.

{@bold Blurred Vision.} Your eyes cloud over, your vision blurs, and distinct shapes become amorphous blobs. You have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks relying on vision and all ranged attacks until treated. Treat with a DC 15 Medicine check over a long rest.

{@bold Weak in the Knees.} Your stamina collapses. If you try to travel for more than an hour at a time, you gain a level of exhaustion. Every time you take a short rest, you can make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw, ending this effect on a success.
{@bold Nausea.} You feel a sick, oily feeling deep in your stomach, and bile rolling up your throat. You have disadvantage on all ability checks. Treat with a DC 16 Medicine check over a short rest.

{@bold Aberrant Interaction.} Any time you drink a potion, there is a 50% chance that it interacts poorly with the lingering poison in your body. If this happens, the potion has no effect and you take {@damage 2d8} poison damage. Treat with a DC 19 Medicine check over a long rest.
{@bold Sickly Tinge.} Your skin develops a slight yellow-green, unhealthy tinge. This fades away after 2d4 long rests.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Psychic
table.caption: Psychic Injury
rows: {@b A Taste of Madness.} You develop a long-term madness, which lasts until treated with a successful DC 19 Insight check by another creature over a long rest. On a failed check, the madness becomes permanent (though it may be cured by {@spell greater restoration} or similarly powerful magic).

{@b Crippling Phobia.} Unconsciously, your brain has made a connection between something random and the pain it felt, and now you cannot help but associate the two. The DM chooses something about the source of the damage or the setting. Any time you move iwthin 15 feet of this phobia, you are {@b frightened} until you move at least 50 feet away from it.

{@bold Tower of Babel.} The language center of your brain has fried. You lose proficiency in all languages, and you cannot read or write; all communication sounds like a garbled string of random words.. Verbal components of spells automatically fail. This injury lasts until treated with a DC 20 Insight check over a long rest, and can be suppressed by a {@spell calm emotion} spell.

{@b Psychic Disruption.} Your mental focus is shattered. You lose the ability to use all Psionic abilities, including telepathy and any ability that mentions 'psi' in the name or description. Treat with a DC 22 Surgery on the brain.
{@bold Headache.} Your head throbs and the light aggravates you. You cannot benefit from a short rest until you complete 1d2 long rests.
{@bold Minor Amnesia.} You feel like you've forgotten something. You lose proficiency in one skill, chosen randomly. Treat by spending a long rest re-training that proficiency.

{@bold Paranoia.} You find it difficult to stop being distracted by the feeling that there is someone or something out to get you. Whenever you must maintain concentration, roll {@dice 1d4}. This is the maximum amount of rounds you may maintain concentration for that spell or effect.
{@bold Nothing.} No injury! Seems almost too good to be true.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Radiant
table.caption: Radiant Injury
rows: {@b Penitent Mercy.} You've lost your stomach for killing. The thought of taking a life fills you with abject discust. You can no longer willingly take a life, and if you reduce a creature to 0 hit points, you immediately gain a level of exhaustion.

{@b Searing Light.} Your eyes are suffused with a horrid, blinding light. You emit bright light to a radius of 10 feet and dim light for another 10 feet, and both of your eyes are {@b nonfunctional}. Treat with a DC 20 Surgery. The {@spell darkness} spell cast on your eyes suppresses the blindness temporarily.

{@bold Purged Soul.} Your soul is partially severed from your body, leaving it exposed and vulnerable. If you die before this is treated, your soul is claimed, and you cannot be resurrected by any means short of a Wish spell. Treat with a DC 25 Religion check over a long rest.

{@bold Irradiated.} The energy that has washed over you has left you with a lingering feeling of sickness and nausea. You are {@condition poisoned}, and every time you take a short or long rest, you lose {@dice 2d8} maximum hit points. You die if this reduces your hit point maximum to 0. Treat with a DC 25 Medicine check over a long rest.

{@bold Seen the Light.} You feel as if you've seen a glimpse of something greater than yourself, and a tiny mote of that light has come to rest on your soul. You gain a flaw that would be considered benevolent, self-sacrificing, unyielding, or militant.
{@bold Sunburn.} The light sears a painful red burn into your skin. You take 1 radiant damage for every 10 feet of movement while in combat. This injury lasts until you complete a long rest.

{@bold Unearthly Glow.} Youa re afflicted by a dull, yellow-green glow, which affects you in the same manner as a {@spell faerie fire} spell, though the effect itself is nonmagical. Treat over a short rest with a DC 18 Religion check.

{@bold Radiant Scar.} Your body now bears a glowing scar that looks like a crack in the skin, which leaks a bright light. You emit bright light in a 5 foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet. Even if you attempt to cover it with cloth or armor, the light is still clearly visible underneath the coverings.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Slashing
table.caption: Slashing Injury
rows: {@b Severed Limb.} One of your limbs has been sliced clean off. It lands severed at your feet and is {@b missing}. Treat with a DC 22 Surgery. The DC increases by 1 for every hour that passes.
{@bold Stubborn Bleeding.} The wound simply won't close. For every hour that passes, you lose 1 hit point. Treat with a DC 22 Surgery.

{@bold Blood Loss.} You've lost a {@i lot} of blood, and are feeling quite weak. You take a -3 penalty to all ability checks, saving throws, attack rolls, and to the save DCs of any of your features. This penalty is reduced by 1 every time you complete a long rest; a successful DC 20 Medicine check over a long rest reduces it by 1 more.

{@bold Severed Nerves.} Some of your nerves have been cut- leaving you in excruciating pain. You cannot maintain concentration on spells and effects, and any time you make an attack or cast a spell, you take {@damage 1d8} piercing damage. Treat with a DC 22 Surgery (and do it soon.)

{@b Severed Appendage.} You're almost {@i impressed} with the accuracy of that blow- it takes a lot of skill to take a nose or a ear clean off. You'd be more impressed if you weren't suddenly missing a body part. One of your ears or your nose is cut clean off, and is considered {@b missing}. Reattach with a DC 20 Surgery; the DC increases by 1 for every hour that passes.
{@bold Slashed Hamstring.} A nasty gash through the leg. Your speed is halved. Treat with a DC 15 Medicine check over a long rest.

{@bold Festering Wound.} The wound looks angyr near the edges, and stubbornly refuses to heal. You cannot heal hit points through any means of nonmagical healing, such as a long or short rest. Treat with a DC 18 Medicine check over a long rest (though if cured over a long rest, you still regain no hit points from that rest.)
{@bold Roguish Scar.} You have a long, thin scar somewhere on your body. It gives you a slightly roguish look, though acquiring more is not recommended.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Necrotic
table.caption: Necrotic Injury
rows: {@b Cursed by Fate.} A malicious curse settles upon your soul. While cursed, you treat any 20 you roll as a 1.

{@b Tenuous Grip on Life.} You feel like you've seen the face of death, and can recall her grim visage with ease. You now require one less failed death saving throw before you must make a Mortality roll.
{@bold Corrupted Vitality.} You can no longer recieve magical healing. Treat with a DC 25 Religion check over a long rest.
{@bold Withering.} For every minute another creature spends near you, they take 1 necrotic damage. Nonmagical plants around you wilt in that same time.

{@b Malevolence.} A small mote of corrupt power has taken residence within you, and you feel a tiny part of your soul become unhinged. You gain a {@i flaw} that would be considered malevolent, violent, cruel, or volatile.

{@bold Necrotic Wound.} Your wound festers with a dark energy that resists both magical and natural healing. Your maximum hit points are reduced by the amount of damage that caused you to fail your last death save. Treat with a DC 18 Surgery.
{@bold Chronoscarred.} Every cell in your body protests as they are assaulted by the flow of time. Your body suddenly ages 2d10 years. Your mind is unaffected.

{@bold Deathly Wound.} You gain an obvious, gaping wound- a hole through your body, or a chunk gnawed out of your arm. Despite the apparent egregious injury, it doesn't seem to hurt at all, though it certainly draws a lot of attention.

table.name: Lingering Injuries: Thunder
table.caption: Thunder Injury
rows: {@b Ruptured Eardrums.} The sonic assault has blown out your eardrums. You are {@b deafened} and your ears are {@b nonfunctional}. If not treated within 24 hours, your hearing will be permanently {@b missing}.

{@b Unlucky Shrapnel.} An unlucky piece of shrapnel has ricocheted straight into your eye, leaving it {@b nonfunctional}. If not treated within 4 hours, your vision is permanently {@b missing} in that eye. Treat with a DC 20 Surgery.

{@bold Barotrauma.} The concussive force reverberates through your lungs, doing major damage. You can no longer hold your breath for longer than 1 round at a time, and shouting causes you to take {@damage 1d4} piercing damage.

{@bold Acoustic Dead Zone.} In a freak instance of chance, the sonic assault interacts with a thread of natural magic within you. Everything around you seems strangely silent. You are enveloped in an aura of silence that fills your space, as per the {@spell silence} spell. Treat with a DC 24 Arcana check over a long rest.

{@bold Shrapnel Destruction.} Shrapnel tears through your armor, rendering it damaged. Your armor or shield takes a -2 penalty to the AC granted; if your armor's base AC is reduced to 10 or lower, it is rendered unusable.
{@bold Unsteady.} Subtle vibrations rock you deep to your core. You have disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws and Acrobatics checks. Treat with a DC 17 Medicine check over a long rest.
{@bold Tinnitus.} You are left with an annoying ringing in your ears. You have disadvantage to Perception checks. Treat with a DC 12 Medicine check over a long rest.
{@bold Speckled Scar.} You've been struck with some ballistic debris, resulting in a painful-looking but harmless scar.

entries: If damage reduces the zombie to 0 hit points, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is radiant or from a critical hit. On a success, the zombie drops to 1 hit point instead.

spell.name: Infernal Bargain

m.text: a high-quality quill plucked from an exotic beast, a vial of spell-quality ink, and ten sheets of high-quality parchment collectively worth 999 gp

entries: Uttering a dark incantation, you summon a devil from the Infernal Bureaucracy. The DM chooses the devil's type, and the summoned devil is challenge rating 6 or lower. The devil appears in an unoccupied space that you can see within range. The devil disappears when it drops to 0 hit points or when the spell ends.

The devil is not under your control, but as a member of the Infernal Bureaucracy is amenable to making a deal. You have ten minutes to strike a bargain with the devil, which is recorded as a magical contract upon the components used for the spell. You may request a service to be accomplished by the devil, who in turn names a price to be paid in exchange for this service, which usually takes the form of a favor or a rare item, though it may also be a less tangible good. Add The devils of the Infernal Bureaucracy have no interest in gold.

If both you and the devil come to an agreement on the deal to be struck, the terms of the contract are inscribed upon the parchment provided as a component of the spell. The devil will fulfill the terms of its bargain to the best of its ability, and a devil never agrees to a bargain that would be impossible for it to complete. Should you violate the terms of the bargain, you immediately die, and your soul is claimed by the Infernal Bureaucracy as payment.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the challenge rating increases by 2 for each slot level above 5th.

entries.name: Special Commission
entries: An item that is marked as Special Commission is not readily available from the average merchant or smith. They may require a special order, or a particularly talented craftsman, or a shady contact to obtain.

entries.name: Black Market
entries: A black market item is at the very least explicitly illegal to buy or sell, and is very often illegal to own. Purchase of black market items can only be done through illegal channels, are subject to complications, and if the customer is not well-integrated into criminal networks, may incur an upcharge in addition to the listed price.

entries.name: Material
entries: This item represents a particular material that can be used to plate certain types of weapons and armor. Some materials, such as silver, can be easily acquired and applied to weapons by any smith, while others require great effort to find the necessary material and a smith with the talent to work it.
An object cannot have more than one material applied to it. See {@variantrule FORGE} for more detail.

entries.name: Staff
entries: A staff is an alternative to a casting focus. Staffs are generally more cumbersome and harder to conceal, but often come with additional benefits over a traditional focus. As long as you are wielding a staff, you may use it as part of the casting of any spell, not just ones that require a material component.
Unlike most weapons and foci, it takes an action to equip and use a staff, as the caster must spend some energy attuning to the magical focus.

Staffs require two hands to use. If you are maintaining concentration on a spell cast using a staff, you must keep hold of the staff with both hands; if you release the staff for any reason, your concentration ends.
